story:
Following a one year studio residency in Chelsea, New York City the Free Agents collective team up with the Miami Light Project to present their debut exhibition – PREMIERE! – a group art exhibition and mural debut during Miami’s Art Basel.

The Free Agents are a collective of autonomous artists from New York City who work out of a shared studio spaces in Chelsea, New York. With roots in urban contemporary art and for many in New York's graffiti culture, the collective collaborates on exhibitions, public murals, lectures, and workshops. The Free Agents are KET, Klass, Carlos Mare, Alice Mizrachi, Phetus, Queen Andrea, and Ezo Wippler.

Founded in 1989, Miami Light Project is a not-for-profit cultural organization which presents live performances by innovative dance, music and theater artists from around the world; supports the development of new work by South Florida-based artists; and offers educational programs for students of every age.

Premiering new works from artists: KET, Klass, Carlos Mare, Alice Mizrachi, Phetus, Queen Andrea, and Ezo Wippler, the exhibition will feature photography, paintings, sculpture, and a site specific mural installation.

This special event will bring together a wide range of artists, young professionals, patrons from a variety of industries including music, art, fashion, and tech.

YOU CAN HELP

With your help we need to raise funds for the artists travel, accommodations, art transport, per diem and production costs. Please see our budget breakdown below. 

ARTIST FLIGHTS, ACCOMODATIONS, AND PER DIEM- 6 Artists.........................$6000

ART TRANSPORT....................................................................................$3000

INSTALLATION COSTS.............................................................................$1000 

MURAL COSTS (PAINT, LIFTS)..................................................................$3000

MUSIC PROGRAMMING (2 nights)...............................................................$2000

YOUR BENEFIT/REWARDS

By donating to PREMIERE you not only help a great idea become a reality but you support the independent arts community and facilitate its advancement on a global level. We are also including some Perks for your support. Please see gallery section above to see pictures of art rewards.

story:
Frequently Asked Questions: A Circus Collective

We are a group of ten circus artists who have come together to create a new circus show for the summer of 2013 and ultimately plan to create a new circus company.

We are currently based out of Montreal where the ten of us study different circus disciplines. Frequently Asked Questions is made up of nine Americans and one member from Finland.

We all come from very different backgrounds but are strongly connected by our passion for circus. With this new show we hope to push our bodies and minds in order to create a truly unique experience for our audience. We have all been trained in both traditional and contemporary settings and plan to reflect our comprehensive foundation in our new show. With this show we hope to provide high quality performances at an affordable price in order to inspire people from all walks of life and spread our passion for the circus. 

We are currently researching venues for next summer and hope to present our show in the North East region of the United States as well as in Quebec, Canada.

How you can help!

We are determined to get this project off the ground and we are fully prepared to commit countless unpaid hours in order to have an extraordinary final product.

The money we raise will be used over the course of this year in order to create our show. Some of our foreseen costs include equipment, transportation, insurance, rehearsal space and promotional material.

As young artists’ we are incredibly grateful for any support you can provide, whether it is a monetary donation or graciously spreading the word about this project.  

We will keep you updated on the progress of our creation and hope to see you all at our shows next summer.

Sincerely,

Sidney Bateman           Eric Brown

Lindsay Culbert-Olds      Melvin Diggs 

Kia Melinda Eastman      Aaron Marquise

Natasha Patterson         Kerttu Pussinen

Daniel Sullivan             Patrick Tobin 

 

CircusFAQ@gmail.com

story:
My name is Amber Doe, I am a sculptor and filmmaker.

 

What is a Doe in Finland?


Me. I have been selected as an Artist in Residence at the Arteles Creative Center in Finland for my birthday month of March (2013). I have been selected based on a proposed light and textile sculpture I will create while at the residency.

Why a light and textile based sculpture in Finland?


Personally, I have always been inspired by textile art and the concept of clothing and textile as forms of communication, self-expression and empowerment. The history of textiles is steeped in the concept of textile work as women's work. Textile production for families, villages and the larger community has always been a way for women in various parts of the world to communicate, express themselves, and illustrate cultural value systems.


Another important theme in my work is the concept of home. Inspired by the fact that the spider creates his own home by spinning an organic substance, I created a sculpture called rope skirt. The rope skirt illustrated both of my thematic preoccupations, the skirt was connected to gender, but the shape of the skirt was abstract and could also be seen as a version of shelter.

 

In Finland, I seek to develop these themes even further using the bee as muse this time instead of the spider. I want to weave a textile out of various light sources in the shape of a bee hive. The structure will be viewed one person at a time. I am curious about the kind of reflection that will take place alone in a light filled space connecting to an art and concept as old as 20,000 BC. The first images from caves in Lespugue, France illustrate a woman wearing a skirt of twisted strings and warm light around her. I believe a piece like the light structure I want to create has the potential to illustrate the connectivity, support and empowerment of females around the world.

 

Finland in the winter would be a beautiful place to view this light and textile sculpture.

 

Your Help


I need your help. I was selected very late in the game and have a very short period of time to raise the necessary funds to make this residency happen. This project will only be possible with the help of many people. I would be so grateful for your help by making a donation of any size. IndieGoGo is a game changer, because if you pay by PayPal , I am able to access funds as soon as they are pledged and most of the expenses will be be due before the end of the drive. Also it is important to know that you don't have to have a PayPal account to donate to this drive.

 

How I will spend the money


Funds raised will pay for 1/2 of my residency fees (Arteles pays the other half), Travel expenses, Food, and Project Materials (which are very expensive in Finland and expensive to ship from the US even if purchased here cheaply)!

 

It is such a huge honor to be selected as an Artist in Residence at Arteles and I would be so humbled and grateful to get the opportunity to practice my art and continue to share it with the world.

 

Sincerely any contribution will help. Please do all you can to spread the word!

I want to add a special thank you to my Dad, Mom, Angeline (2nd mom), Tracy, Linda, Alisha, Kathryn, Genevieve and Brandon.

story:
Here's the scoop

I'm headed to Ethiopia in November with the The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) to assist in their critical aid work relating to clean water, education, and health. Almost half of all Ethiopian children are malnourished, two thirds haven't attended secondary school, and almost 80% don't have access to clean drinking water. Meeting with development professionals on the ground and helping them improve infrastructure to combat these issues will hopefully go a long way to both improve the situation on the ground and raise awareness of the larger problems facing the region.

Help me help others! Your donation will help me cover program costs. In appreciation, I will help you decorate with original art. I've listed a range of ditigal and hand-painted prints and some other fun goodies that can all be yours. 

What you get

It's art for a cause. See photos of the pieces in question in the gallery tab. Because this is a trip through the JDC, the art is Jewish-themed. If that's not your bag, email me and we'll figure something out that suits you better. If you live in LA, or if you live in New York and you contribute before October 22, I'll hand-deliver your gift as well. You are also welcome to donate without claiming a item.

What I do

In my day-job as an LA-based graphic designer and artist, you can often find me outside my apartment, spray paint in hand, stenciling the afternoon away.  I've exhibited pieces in shows around LA, and I'm a winner of the SEDER arts grant for my spray paint pieces. I taught stenciling to middle and high schoolers at Camp Ramah and will be teaching at day schools around LA in the coming year.

I work with a range of non-profits and small businesses from across the Jewish spectrum and beyond, including The Jewish Federation, Aish International, Pressman, YULA, Shalhevet, Temple Beth Hillel, and others, helping them better represent their messages and educate their audiences. 

Where it all goes

Money raised will go directly to program and travel costs as I travel across the world to help those in need. Any funds exceeding program costs will be split between supporting the JDC in their missions aiding communities worldwide and toward future community art programming in Los Angeles, including better safety equipment for my classes with kids and teens, and supplies and legal permits for a planned community mural. 

What else you can do

Do you know people who like art? People who like Ethiopia? People? Pass this on! Also, if you have any school supplies (backpacks, pencils, notebooks, etc.) or clothes and shoes you'd like to me to bring to Ethiopia, let me know so we can make arrangements.

story:
VISIT MY WEBSITE BELOW TO SEE ALL OF MY WORK

http://cargocollective.com/charliegoeringfineart

 

 

The why.

My name is Charlie Goering. I am a young painter entering my junior year in college. I am in the process transfering to Laguna College of Art and Design from the Art Academy of Cincinnati. My current education was severly lacking in helping me to learn what I want to learn which is represetational painting. I need help funding gas, food and some lodging on my trip across our beautiful country with my brother. We plan on leaving the first week in August and travelling the whole month. The plan is to take a northern route arching up and driving down into Laguna Beach. Once we have arrived I will move into my new place, my brother will fly home, and I will begin school.

My calling to become an artist came at an early age. I always drew as a young boy, but through the influence ofmy best friend in 2004, I began taking art classes with local artist, Keith Klein. From the very first time I stepped foot in his studio I knew the path my life was to take. I was blessed early on to have figured out what I wanted to do with my life. My goal in life to be most successful and be the best painter I can be.

Outlined below is my detailed Ciriculm Vite showing my hunger for the craft of painting and success.

CV

Education
Class of 2015 BFA Laguna College of Art and Design
2012-2013 In the studio of Richard Luschek II
2012 Workshop with Colleen Barry, Boston Academy of Realist Art
2012 Workshop with Richard Luschek II
2010 Kentucky Governors School for the Arts
2010 Early College Program, Figure Painting, School of the Art Institute of Chicago
2008 Workshop with Carl Samson
2004-2011 Keith Klein Art Studio

Solo Exhibitions
2013 me,now: A Self Directed Sophomore Show, Art Academy of Cincinnati
2013 Coffee Emporium
2012 Reality Tuesday Cafe

Group Exhibitions
2013 Duveneck Memorial Art Show
2013 Art Academy Students Respond to Hema Upadhyay and Atul Dodiya, Contemporary Arts Center
2013 Essex Studio Art Walk: Scaped
2013 26th Annual Minumental Show, Convergy’s Gallery
2013 Anna Menefee Tribute Exhibition, Chidlaw Gallery
2012 What Makes the Reindeer Fly?, Lloyd Library and Museum
2012 Art Academy of Cincinnati Scholarship Exhibition, Chidlaw Gallery
2011 People Who Draw People, Chidlaw Gallery
2011 25th Annual Minumental Show, Convergy's Gallery
2011 Duveneck Memorial Art Show
2010 A Global Affair; Carnegie Center For Visual and Performing Arts
2010 High School Invitational Exhibition; Eva G. Ferris Gallery, Thomas Moore College
2010 Duveneck Memorial Art Show
2009 Duveneck Memorial Art Show

Awards
2012 Helms Trust Purchase Award, Art Academy of Cincinnati
2011 Art Academy of Cincinnati Scholarship Award Recipient
2011 3rd Place in the Covington Art Club High School Competition
2011 2nd Place in Painting KYAEA Regional High School Art Competition
2011 Duveneck Memorial Art Show 3rd place in painting
2010 Duveneck Memorial Art Show Vox Populi award
2010 Duveneck Memorial Art Show 3rd place in painting 
2010 Kentucky Governors School for the Arts
2009 Cincinnati Art Association Overture Awards Semi-finalist
2008 Cincinnati Art Association Overture Awards Semi-finalist
2007 Kentucky Child Now Choice Artist for the Creative Youth Expo

Collections
Art Academy of Cincinnati

 

What I Need & What You Get

The Budget

Estimated Fuel cost:$1,200

Lodging $400 (We will camp when possible)

Food:$200

Misc: $200

 

The incentives:

Every dollar counts! If you are willing to back me there are four great incetives!

  • With a donation of $25 you recieve a signed print of a paitning of your choice off my website.
  • With a donation of $200 you recieve a Plein Air landscape painting created along my journey
  • With a donation of $500 you will recieve a 11x14 commissioned painting (excludes portraits)
  • With a Donation of $1000 you will recieve an 16x20 commssioned painting

The Impact:

I will be Painting and drawing along the way documenting my travels in a sketchbook, through paitning, as well as photography. Your contriubution would help to elivaite some of the monetariy pressures of making this big move. It would also help me on my journey towards a better education and successful carreer. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Along my journey I will be posting on my art facebook page and Instagram. You can help by liking or following me on these social newworks and spreading the word about my campaign.

Like my facebook page:

https://www.facebook.com/CharlieGoeringArt

Follow me on Instagram:

@charliegoeringfineart

http://instagram.com/charliegoeringfineart

Share this campaign on facebook!

story:
There is always something different going on at The Toast. A volunteer-run community gathering space like no other, it promotes artistic and creative practice of all kinds. Whether it is a visual artist’s first exhibition or a seasoned musician entertaining old and new friends over Sunday breakfast, The Toast keeps it inclusive and financially accessible for artists and participants. With your help we can keep it that way!

This didn’t happen overnight, The Toast grew into the rad space it is today from, of all things, a weekly neighbourhood KICKBALL game...

"The storefront space became available as it would every few months in between tenants who obviously did not have any business plan… So, with a new found community built from weekly kickball games across Kingsway (in Robson Park), we were able to find 8 tenants willing to pitch in to make a "project" happen in that space. The original idea, and the reason why The Toast has its name, is that we were going to open a coffee shop that only served toast... 'all kinds of breads and all kinds of spreads' was our motto. The idea was great, but the delivery was... non-existent....every time we would get together for a meeting everyone would re-energize everyone."

--founding organizer, Charles (the great) Latimer

So fast forward 7 years, and a change of hands, a whole lot of the same and many new lovely faces keeping things going. There have been hundreds of artist and community led, initiated, and dreamed up processes, events and happenings in our cozy space, AND two significant rent increases.

The Toast is a key venue and cultural asset for art, music, and activism in the landscape of alternative Vancouver spaces. We want to continue to stay open, offer affordable and accessible space, and foster relationships with our ever changing neighbours and community that is growing around us.  


What do we mean by keeping things going?

Each month a lot of local artists, community organizers and social groups get together to activate The Toast in so many exciting and refreshing ways. We serve upwards of 50 people a week for ongoing and one off events.  Music, food, books, art, the list goes on, we have seen the wild and the tame come through our doors, hang on the walls, and sometimes need to be cleaned off of the bathroom floor.

Our Collective Membership consists of Beer Cat Brewing Co-op, Junktion Kickball League, and General Assembly, an ongoing arts and curatorial project.  Our regular renters are Mount Pleasant Regional Institute of Sound (MPRIS) and a book club. Our event programming requests are on an ongoing basis and new things always are happening in the space, with the support and collaboration of the Collective Membership.  

So, where do you come in?

As mentioned our rent has increased, and this has become a serious barrier to our continued existence.  Lots of things that happen in the space are based on in-kind transactions, sharing and doing-it-together work ethic. The artists themselves are not making a lot of money, so we cannot charge them as if they were.  

We need your help as we are running ourselves thin (but having a lot of fun doing it!). Besides a core Collective Membership that contributes to the rent at The Toast each month, we hold lots of events, workshops, and other happenings, many of which raise funds to contribute to our costs: they are the key to our survival. But they are not enough. Though we would love it if you could attend everything, in lieu of your direct participation in dozens of events, we are asking our community, and our community's community, to contribute to The Toast Collective. By doing this, you will be supporting so many amazing and worthy projects that the good, creative, and kind people of Vancouver have dreamed up.

Be a part of keeping this amazing space alive. Your contribution will go directly toward establishing a fund for paying the rent when the month is longer than the money, and will help buy us time while we continue to explore new strategies and look for additional ways to make the space more sustainable.

With your help we can keep it that way!This didn’t happen overnight, The Toast grew into the rad space it is today from, of all things, a weekly neighbourhood KICKBALL game..."The storefront space became available as it would every few months in between tenants who obviously did not have any business plan… So, with a new found community built from weekly kickball games across Kingsway (in Robson Park), we were able to find 8 tenants willing to pitch in to make a "project" happen in that space. The original idea, and the reason why The Toast has its name, is that we were going to open a coffee shop that only served toast... 'all kinds of breads and all kinds of spreads' was our motto. The idea was great, but the delivery was... non-existent....every time we would get together for a meeting everyone would re-energize everyone."--founding organizer, Charles (the great) Latimer
So fast forward 7 years, and a change of hands, a whole
lot of the same and many new lovely faces keeping things going. There have been hundreds of artist and community led, initiated, and dreamed up processes, events and happenings in our cozy space, AND two significant rent increases.The Toast is a key venue and cultural asset for art, music, and activism in the landscape of alternative Vancouver spaces. We want to continue to stay open, offer affordable and accessible space, and foster relationships with our ever changing neighbours and community that is growing around us.  What do we mean by keeping things going? Each month a lot of local artists, community organizers and social groups get together to activate The Toast in so many exciting and refreshing ways. We serve upwards of 50 people a week for ongoing and one off events.  Music, food, books, art, the list goes on, we have seen the wild and the tame come through our doors, hang on the walls, and sometimes need to be cleaned off of the bathroom floor. Our Collective Membership consists of Beer Cat Brewing Co-op, Junktion Kickball League, and General Assembly, an ongoing arts and curatorial project.  Our regular renters are Mount Pleasant Regional Institute of Sound (MPRIS) and a book club. Our event programming requests are on an ongoing basis and new things always are happening in the space, with the support and collaboration of the Collective Membership.  So, where do you come in? As mentioned our rent has increased, and this has become a serious barrier to our continued existence.  Lots of things that happen in the space are based on in-kind transactions, sharing and doing-it-together work ethic. The artists themselves are not making a lot of money, so we cannot charge them as if they were.  We need your help as we are running ourselves thin (but having a lot of fun doing it!). Besides a core Collective Membership that contributes to the rent at The Toast each month, we hold lots of events, workshops, and other happenings, many of which raise funds to contribute to our costs: they are the key to our survival. But they are not enough. Though we would love it if you could attend everything, in lieu of your direct participation in dozens of events, we are asking our community, and our community's community, to contribute to The Toast Collective. By doing this, you will be supporting so many amazing and worthy projects that the good, creative, and kind people of Vancouver have dreamed up. Be a part of keeping this amazing space alive. Your contribution will go directly toward establishing a fund for paying the rent when the month is longer than the money, and will help buy us time while we continue to explore new strategies and look for additional ways to make the space more sustainable.

story:
Hey everyone its Danny G and Eric Piper. For 6 months we have bled, sweated,cursed and create that body of work dealing with identity in relation to both physical and mental environments. We are going on an international print and performance tour in which I (Danny G) never thought was possible.

What is the HELIOS CIRCUIT?

Helios Circuit is an 8 week tour that travels across 24 states and 7 different countries. 

 Already confirmed 33 collaborating artists and a variety of show locations from street art interventions to house openings, DIY Venues to white wall gallery performances and exhibitions. Helios Circuit will team up this year with Diverse Universe, a nomadic performance festival that is in it’s 11th edition. 

Diverse Universe 2015 will involve over 200 artists over 8 weeks, physically linking 25 European cities across 14 countries, and attracting a combined audience of over 15,000 people. 

 We will be working with local artists and organizers to set up a show to maximize interaction between local and traveling artists. We also will be networking with artists we meet to set up shows and residencies back at our experimental gallery in Oklahoma. Along with presenting their own high quality artwork, participating artists work together to run workshops, seminars, collaborative performances, and discussions. 

 These activities are organized with both young local artists and professional organizations. We plan symposia and network meetings to connect the local, regional and global to one another. These activities allow the participants to share experience, ideas, concepts, and art. 

This cross fertilization of culture pushes us to create more effective, more exciting, and more meaningful artwork to share with the world. 

 Your contribution to Helios Circuit 2015 will help us pay for: transporting collaborating artists and cultural professionals, help pay for artist’s stipend, help set back costs of setting up show locations, help pay for high profile, targeted publicity for the tour, and help us publish digital and physical documentation of the tour for future generations to explore.


 By contributing to this fund raiser we will be able to achieve our goals of bridging a divide in cultures through the universal language of art. We're in the home stretch now and are about $2000 short. The money that you contribute will go to purchasing the last few materials we need to bring the art to life, and to help us tour.

For every person that contributes they will receive hand designed post cards from both me and Eric while we are touring europe. Even if our goal isnt met the money that had been donated will still help us reach our goal. 

Now some might ask what is my contribution going to do besides help us.. 

Well by helping us you ensure that we, as Oklahomans, will become ambassadors to our great state (and there-in US ambassadors). That people from all over world will realize, despite negative stereotypes, we have a rich culture and progressive vision. That in one of the most difficult places to live in the country; art,culture, and respect still emanates through the storm. In a few short weeks we will be faced with a strenuous journey pushing our wills and bodies to the limit..But with you our family, loved ones, and friends at our backs we will succeed. 

The impediment to action advances action. What stands in the way, becomes the way."  Marcus Aurelius

story:
THEATRUM CHEMICUM

This will be the first video of an on-going series that explores alchemic traditions through a fusion of art, performance, fashion and design. Each video is one part of a transformative journey that slowly reveals more clues, characters and stunning locations. In this oneiric world, anything is possible.  

The first video of the series will be filmed in Berlin; where the city’s architecture and atmosphere matches our alchemic vision. 

Each location in Berlin will be transformed by the performers within the space and props and costumes in vibrant, rich colours such as royal blue, turquoise, ochre, red, maroon and white. Amalgamating into what will look like a moving painting.

Please watch the video above to get a taster of the video series to come... We have included images from a test shoot we did with photographer Louie Vignat to give you an idea of the mood of the film. 

THE COLLABORATORS so far..

This is an ongoing collaborative project between multidisciplinary creatives such as artists, designers, performers and video-makers- It is directed by artists Moon-Age and Hellza House. 

Moon-Age

Moon-age is a multi-media artist and stylist originating from Australia. Moon-Age seeks to integrate her experience in art direction and styling for photo shoots and music videos with performance work influenced by Butoh and the Theatre of the Grotesque.  She is now creating experimental electronic music which she will use as the glue for the Theatrum Chemicum series.

Moon-Age has contributed her visual talents to the likes of Iggy Azelia, Tank Magazine, Show Studio, Vice Magazine, Schon Magazine, Channel 4 (UK). 

Her work has been shown at The Center Pompidu in Paris, SONAR multi-media festival in Spain as well as in group and solo shows in Sydney and Berlin. Moon-Age also curates a series of immersive events known as 'Chapel Perilous' in London and now in Berlin, in which she seeks to break down the barriers between performance and audience. 

Hellza Haus

Hellza is a multi-media artist living and working in Berlin. Throughout her creative life she engaged with different forms of artistic expression such as sculpture, fashion, photography, music and physical theatre. Today she creates images and videos which make use of these multi-disciplinary experiences, combining different skills and enjoying a broader perspective on the creative process.

Whether designing sets and costumes, developing concepts or directing, Hellza is passionate about creating sublime visuals with other-worldly symbolism. Her colourful images make use of simple materials such and paper and fabric, these can transform and morph in real time to create an organic atmosphere.

Producer: Erin McBean

Director of Photography: http://tobijall.com/

Choreographer: http://rebecca-halls.com/

Still Photography: Louie Vignat

LET'S MAKE IT HAPPEN 

To get this project off the ground we need the following: 

  • film equipment- Camera hire, lighting
  • materials for costumes- We are creating numerous intricate costumes also in collaboration with Designers Mary Benson and Andrew Yates
  • materials for props- All props will be especially created for the film
  • location
  • catering
  • van hire 

We want to give people a story to follow, a visual puzzle to unravel, using the internet as a vehicle. 

The creators involved are alchemist's in they are seeking to transform themselves through the creative process and other pursuits such as meditation, travel, workshops, body work, ritual, play and collaboration. 

We hope to inspire others to fuse together different modes of expression and make exciting use of the spaces available to them in their city.

THE FUTURE

We hope to expand the project in future, and film in locations across the globe. We will update our blog and use the internet to exhibit the story. The website is currently being designed by Marylin Rose and will be launched with the film. 

We hope to eventually create exquisite live performances which incorporate live music and the characters and themes within Theatrum Chemicum. 

We would like to involve various experts in creative fields- film makers, dancers, set makers, fashion designers. 

Here is a costume in the making for one of the characters, by Andrew Yates...

Hellza Haus at work on a mask...


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP US 

Share this and follow us on our journey @berlinalchemy 


The Perks include orignial artworks and limited edition prints of Moon-Age's drawings- here are examples of her work.

Chapel Perilous Perk:

Performance and multi-media works curated by Moon-Age- Taking place July 26th, at Mind Pirates Berlin

MOON-AGE PRESS

Hunger Magazine: http://www.hungertv.com/feature/get-know-moonage/

Huck Magazine: http://www.huckmagazine.com/art-and-culture/art-2/immersive-performance-art/

'Alex Moon-Age part artist, performer, collector, and fashion freak that works between the cracks of the surreal and curious. Moon-Age brought artistic direction from another sphere, glam and flipped-out ritual to Dirty Electronics’ video for Sonar, Barcelona, 2013, and colour-crazy jumpsuited extravagance to performances together in London. Hard to miss, easy to frill. One of the most alluring and creative minds I know.'

John Richards, Dirty Electronics, 2014

'Moon-age is a cutting edge artist who has a extraordinary original vision, a unique and dazzling sense of aesthetic that, like the very best art accesses the inner reaches of our consciousness and takes us to a surreal and dreamy landscape of the soul. A true future feminist I was honoured to have her a student and be part of her incredible journey in the beginning or her practice. Great things are afoot from Moon-age watch her and cherish her!'

Marisa Carnesky, Carnesky Productions (London), 2014

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP US 

Share this and follow us on our journey @berlinalchemy

story:
Jacob Lawrence Migration Series Microsite

The Phillips Collection, America's first museum of modern art, endeavors to launch a microsite based around celebrated American artist Jacob Lawrence's epic The Migration Series. The site will feature never-before-published video interviews with the artist conducted at The Phillips Collection in 1993 and 2000, along with high-resolution images of all 60 panels in the series, biographical materials, an interactive map, archival photographs, and audio and video clips of musical, literary, and historical events of the time. The interactive site will engage visitors with the powerful history and contemporary context of migration through the lens of Lawrence's striking visual masterwork.
This is a particularly critical moment as the launch of the microsite will coincide with the co-organized exhibition Jacob Lawrence: The Migration Series that will be presented at the Museum of Modern Art in New York in spring 2015 and then at the Phillips in fall 2016.  

More Than Halfway There

We're already well on our way to creating this exciting project, thanks to the support of the below generous donors:

  • Judy and Leo Zickler and the Zickler Family Foundation
  • A. Fenner Milton
  • Henry Luce Foundation
These supporters have brought us 60 percent of the way to our goal—but we need you to reach our total goal of $125,000!

Bring Resources to Millions

The art and life of Jacob Lawrence have long been an inspiration to The Phillips Collection. Through a number of in-depth initiatives conducted over several decades, the Phillips has gathered a treasure trove of knowledge and insight about Jacob Lawrence. Visitors to the site will be able to access these vast resources by selecting from three “tracks” that include segments of the museum’s never-before-published video interviews with the artist along with:

  • Art: High-resolution images of all 60 panels with text explaining each work
  • Culture: The life and times of Lawrence through archival photographs, sound clips, and videos of musical acts, theatrical performances, and historical events
  • Artist: Lawrence’s personal history, a biographical and autobiographical sketch chronicling his life
By contributing to this campaign, you ensure that these extensive resources reach education systems, scholars, researchers, and historians across the globe. Among other things, the microsite:
  • Complements Lawrence’s first-hand accounts with a multiplicity of the latest contemporary views on migration from scholars across disciplines
  • Engages audiences in the theme of migration from the rich perspectives of visual culture as well as music, theater, film, and poetry
  • Highlights the events that inspired Lawrence to create the series
  • Connects images of his 60 paintings to archival photographs captured during the time of the migrations
  • Spotlights milestones of America’s Great Migration, highlighting dates and cities on an animated map of the nation 
Audiences are invited to share their own migration stories through poetry and art, including submitting their own design for what “Panel 61” might look like today.

What Your Gift Provides

We want you to know the impact of your donation and where that money will go. Your gift will help us reach these benchmarks:

$100,000                   Production costs
$10,000                      Licensing and rights fees
$15,000                      Site maintenance and updates for five years
$125,000                TOTAL

About Jacob Lawrence

A celebrated painter, storyteller, and interpreter of the African American experience, Jacob Lawrence (1917–2000) is one of the most important American artists of the 20th century. He discovered art as a means of expression while a teenager in New York City during the 1930s where he fully experienced the vitality of the Harlem Renaissance. Throughout his long career, Lawrence fixed his gaze firmly on the complexity of our American tumult, from the Civil War of the 1860s to the Civil Rights Movement of the 1960s.

About The Migration Series

Jacob Lawrence’s Migration Series (1940–41), a sequence of 60 paintings, depicts the mass movement of African Americans from the rural South to the urban North between World War I and World War II—a development that had received little previous public attention.

Lawrence spent months distilling the subject into captions and preliminary drawings and preparing 60 boards with the help of his wife. He created the paintings in tempera, a water-base paint that dries rapidly. To keep the colors consistent, Lawrence applied one hue at a time to every painting where it was to appear, requiring him to plan all 60 paintings in detail at once. The series was the subject of a solo show at the Downtown Gallery in Manhattan in 1941, making Lawrence the first black artist represented by a New York gallery. Interest in the series was intense. Ultimately, The Phillips Collection and New York’s Museum of Modern Art agreed to divide it, with the Phillips buying the odd-numbered paintings.

Jacob Lawrence and The Phillips Collection

In 1942, museum founder Duncan Phillips expressed great enthusiasm for Lawrence’s Migration Series upon seeing it at the Downtown Gallery. That year, Phillips gave Lawrence his first solo museum exhibition, and soon after purchased the odd numbered panels. The Phillips has remained deeply committed to sharing and expanding Lawrence’s legacy and achievements with broad and diverse audiences.

  • In the 1990s, the Phillips organized an eight-city national tour of the complete Migrations Series. It also led a major study of Lawrence’s life through symposia, conferences, and interdisciplinary panels.
  • In 2000, Lawrence personally selected the Phillips to organize his retrospective. The highly-acclaimed exhibition premiered at the Phillips and traveled to five other major cities.
  • In 2007–08, the Phillips launched a five-venue NEA American Masterpieces touring exhibition featuring selections from the series. The tour brought Lawrence’s masterpiece to underserved communities throughout the US and was accompanied by a major educational outreach program.
The museum has led an ongoing educational dialogue with the community about The Migration Series for more than 20 years, from focus groups with community group leaders, to an array of innovative programming including storytelling, literacy programs, professional development for teachers, outreach programs for at-risk students, and music programs.

Share The #LawrenceLegacy

Help us spread the word! Use #LawrenceLegacy and the share tools at the top of this page to alert your social media networks or e-mail this campaign to a friend. Check back here and on The Phillips Collection's blog, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and Google + accounts for updates.

story:
Voices of Compassion Project

What it is, who is chosen, and why?
  • Portraits done of influential and inspiring people who use their influence in music, poetry, journalism, activism, and literature to fight violence or mistreatment of human beings all over the world. 
  • The drawings are created using the person's own words and are meant to show not only a likeness of the person, but also some of their values and motivations in life. It's meant to be a more comprehensive look at a individual than traditional portraiture. 
  • I want to help fundraise and help spread these heroes' message of compassion and hope through art and with donations from my fans!


Who I am and why I am doing this...

  • I am Michael Volpicelli, an artist from the Philadelphia area. I am best known for my word art style of drawing, where I draw realistic looking portraits using only words. I am using this talent currently to try and spread the words of people who I believe are motivational and have positive messages. I think that through art, a person can make a ripple all over the world and influence people to help reinforce ideals of love, peace, and compassion for all people.  
  • I believe that this goal is important because it's sad to turn on the news and see wars everywhere. Recently I had a baby girl named Lorelei, and I don't want her growing up in a world where people are so cruel and negative towards each other. So I want to make a difference.

What I am looking to achieve through this fundraiser...


  • I want to create a series of 5-6 drawings of influencal people from all over the world with a positive message and create a cohesive series. I am asking for donations because it takes a lot of time to research each person and then to complete each drawing. Your donation will be split, so 50% of it will go to the different foundations and charities supported by the people I choose to draw, and the other 50% will go to me as the artist so I can pay for gallery fees and expenses, pay for supplies , and be able to market this project effectively.
The remaining 50% will go to the charities, and organizations such as:
  • The Mattie J.T. Stepanek Foundation. They spread messages of hope and peace by offering educational programs, activities, and resources that support an understanding of peace.  http://www.mattieonline.com
  • Gua Africa, which supports education in South Africa. No more child soldiers! http://www.gua-africa.org
  • The Malala Fund, which supports issues involving young woman all over the world. The goal is to give access to a high quality education to young women on a community level. http://www.malala.org
  • ...and more to come...
Lets make a difference in the world one piece of artwork at a time! And if I do not reach my goal all funds will still be equally divided between myself and the listed foundations above.
You can also see what I am up to and past work I have done on Facebook  @ https://www.facebook.com/masterworkartistry

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Tell me about the people you think would make great additions to this series! 

    Share and like on Facebook and other types of social media! The more people that do that, the more Facebook markets the series which hopefully brings in more money for the organizations above!

    Tell people! Tell newspapers! Post on Blogs! Donate a nickel. Every little bit counts!
story_txt:
Voices of Compassion Project
What it is, who is chosen, and why?


Portraits done of influential and inspiring people who use their influence in music, poetry, journalism, activism, and literature to fight violence or mistreatment of human beings all over the world. 
The drawings are created using the person's own words and are meant to show not only a likeness of the person, but also some of their values and motivations in life. It's meant to be a more comprehensive look at a individual than traditional portraiture. 
I want to help fundraise and help spread these heroes' message of compassion and hope through art and with donations from my fans!



Who I am and why I am doing this...

I am Michael Volpicelli, an artist from the Philadelphia area. I am best known for my word art style of drawing, where I draw realistic looking portraits using only words. I am using this talent currently to try and spread the words of people who I believe are motivational and have positive messages. I think that through art, a person can make a ripple all over the world and influence people to help reinforce ideals of love, peace, and compassion for all people.  

I believe that this goal is important because it's sad to turn on the news and see wars everywhere. Recently I had a baby girl named Lorelei, and I don't want her growing up in a world where people are so cruel and negative towards each other. So I want to make a difference.



What I am looking to achieve through this fundraiser...

I want to create a series of 5-6 drawings of influencal people from all over the world with a positive message and create a cohesive series. I am asking for donations because it takes a lot of time to research each person and then to complete each drawing. Your donation will be split, so 50% of it will go to the different foundations and charities supported by the people I choose to draw, and the other 50% will go to me as the artist so I can pay for gallery fees and expenses, pay for supplies , and be able to market this project effectively.

The remaining 50% will go to the charities, and organizations such as:


The Mattie J.T. Stepanek Foundation. They spread messages of hope and peace by offering educational programs, activities, and resources that support an understanding of peace.  http://www.mattieonline.com

Gua Africa, which supports education in South Africa. No more child soldiers! http://www.gua-africa.org

The Malala Fund, which supports issues involving young woman all over the world. The goal is to give access to a high quality education to young women on a community level. http://www.malala.org

...and more to come...

Lets make a difference in the world one piece of artwork at a time! And if I do not reach my goal all funds will still be equally divided between myself and the listed foundations above.

You can also see what I am up to and past work I have done on Facebook  @ https://www.facebook.com/masterworkartistry


  Other Ways You Can Help Tell me about the people you think would make great additions to this series! 
Share and like on Facebook and other types of social media! The more people that do that, the more Facebook markets the series which hopefully brings in more money for the organizations above!
Tell people! Tell newspapers! Post on Blogs! Donate a nickel. Every little bit counts!

story:
Meet Tricia and Stephen Preston

Hello, hello!  Thanks for stopping by!  We are so glad you have decided to have a look at our campaign!   We're a husband and wife team who've recently fulfilled a dream to write and illustrate our own children's book.  After years of painting and drawing,  I (Tricia) discovered my unique style through doodling and I began on a new journey of whimsy.  A lot of the illustrations in the book were inspired by doodles that I brought to life with bold colours.  My musical husband Stephen also came along side and took my story line and added his fun whimsical rhymes into the mix.   "On Top Of the World" is packed full of adventure and fun.   It's our desire that as children read and look through the pages, that the fun and adventure that is inside of them will come to life and their imaginations will soar.  One of our dreams is to make a living through our creations (artistic, written, and musically) and this is part of our adventure.  We'd be so grateful to have you stop by our website and check out what all we up to (www.funtasticalstudios.com).  We also have a heart for children and a desire to help those that are less privileged.  So as part of our campaign, we will be donating 10% of all funds raised to Mannarelief (www.mannarelief.org), a non-profit organization that helps provide nutrition to malnourished children around the world.


What We Need & What You Get

In order to see our book go from draft pages into print, we are hoping to raise $2000 through our Indiegogo campaign.  This will allow us to get 100 copies of our book printed and shipped out as well as cover some of our costs in pre-production.  I'm sure you're asking "What do I get out of this?"  Well, not only do you get the incredible and fulfilling chance to help someone see a dream come to pass,  but you also get to choose from some amazing thank you gifts and packages.  

$1 donation: Every little bit counts, so for donating just $1 you will get a shout out on our social media pages thanking you for your donation!

$10 donation: You get a personal shout out on our social media pages, plus you get a digital copy (PDF) of the book for your enjoyment and to share with your friends.

$20 donation: You get a personal shout out on our social media pages, a digital copy (PDF) of the book for your enjoyment and to share with your friends, plus a hardcover copy of "On Top of the World."

$25 donation: You get a personal shout out on our social media pages, a digital copy (PDF) of the book for your enjoyment and to share with your friends, plus a personalized and signed note in your hardcover copy of "On Top Of the World."

$30 donation: You get a personal shout out on our social media pages, a digital copy (PDF) of the book for your enjoyment and to share with your friends, plus a personalized and signed note in your hardcover copy of "On Top Of the World," plus and original 6x6 doodle by the co-author and illustrator Tricia Preston.

$50 donation: You get to choose from two $50 options.  1)You get a personal shout out on our social media pages, a digital copy (PDF) of the book for your enjoyment and to share with your friends, plus a personalized and signed note in your hardcover copy of "On Top Of the World", plus a second signed copy of the book with a personalized dedication inscribed, or 2)Instead of a second copy of the book you get an 8 x 10 print of the cover.

$100 donation: You get a personal shout out on our social media pages, a digital copy (PDF) of the book for your enjoyment and to share with your friends, plus a personalized and signed note in your hardcover copy of "On Top Of the World" plus an 8x10 print of the cover, plus two 8x10 art prints and package of 8 cards of the artists work from other projects.

$350 donation: You get a personal shout out on our social media pages, a digital copy (PDF) of the book for your enjoyment and to share with your friends, plus a personalized and signed note in your hardcover copy of "On Top Of the World" plus an 8x10 print of the cover, and an original 16 x 20 canvas painting by the co-author and illustrator Tricia Preston of one of the illustrations in the book.

$500 donation:  You get a personal shout out on our social media pages, a digital copy (PDF) of the book for your enjoyment and to share with your friends, plus a personalized and signed note in your hardcover copy of "On Top Of the World" plus an 8x10 print of the cover, and an original 18 x 24 canvas painting by the co-author and illustrator Tricia Preston of one of the illustrations in the book.

$500 donation:  Partner with us in distributing the book.  You get a personal shout out on our social media pages, a digital copy (PDF) of the book for your enjoyment and to share with your friends, plus a personalized and signed note in your hardcover copy of "On Top Of the World."  You also get 25 copies of On Top Of the World for you to sell or give away to whomever you choose.

And remember that no matter what level you choose to support us in, you will also be helping to provide nutrition to needy kids around the world!  


The Impact

As we said above, we believe that life should be filled with fun and adventure.  On Top of the World is in some respects a bit of our own story in our journey of living our lives to the fullest!  We are praying that as children (and children in adult bodies!) read the story, that they will be inspired to be who they are designed to be....living a life that embraces the adventure that is destined for them.   Again, one of our dreams is to make a living through our creations (artistic, written, and musically) so please stop by our website and have a look around (www.funtasticalstudios.com).  So you would be helping us live this dream out as well.  Of course there's also the added impact of supporting children around the world with nutrition , as a portion of funds raised will be donated to Mannarelief. (www.mannarelief.org)


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If for some reason you are unable to donate at this time, but love what we are doing,  there is still a way for you to help us out.  Help us get the word out by making some noise about our campaign on social media!  Share it with your friends.  Expand our reach.  You can use the Indiegogo share tools to post to your social media sites.  Any help you are able to give in this way is greatly appreciated!!  

    Thanks again for checking us out.  May you be blessed with a life filled with fun and adventure as you partner with us in this journey!

story:
I am so excited that I have been nominated for a month-long apexart residency in Seoul, South Korea. Travel expenses are covered but I am raising funds for food expenses.

apexart's Outbound residency "program recognizes the necessity of time for contemplation in the creative process and residents are asked to consider their stay as a break from their professional life. In lieu of applying the pressure of production and career promotion, apexart’s program provides a more introspective and academic alternative that encourages residents to take a step back to consider, interpret, and discuss artistic work and practices."

For the month of July I will be in Seoul, experiencing the culture and taking a break from art production and deadlines. It is a great opportunity for me to leave my comfort zone and experience a culture that I am completely unfamiliar with. I will keep you updated about my adventures on my blog.

I am raising $1500 to cover my food expenses.

For the duration of the residency, I will not be producing any new work. The perks that I am offering are my poetry/recipe chapbooks; sharing information on how to begin a career as an artist; all natural herbal remedies; and sharing information on how to create your own all-natural herbal remedies.

Any contribution is greatly appreciated. However, even if you are unable to contribute financially at this time, please help me to spread the word. Indiegogo makes it easy by providing share buttons for social media.

If you would like to contribute a certain amount but do not like the perk, you can opt out of it and contact me to arrange something else.


Disclaimer: Any herbal information or remedies I offer are not intended to diagnose or cure any illness. Please consult a licensed healthcare practitioner for medical advice or treatment

story:
We are a group of six fine art students currently studying at Bath School of Art and Design. 

Our aim is to exhibit our graduate show in London's Protein Gallery. (26th-29th June)

What We Need & What You Get

WE NEED YOUR HELP!

Your donations will help us to cover the costs of hiring the venue, transporting our work to and from London, advertising/promoting the exhibition and also help to the costs of the private view.

The Impact

This exciting opportunity will be the first graduate show that Protein has showcased in their newly located space in Shoreditch.

It is an fantastic chance for us to show our work in this gallery as it is internationally recognised.  It will also be the first time that we have exhibited in London  as a group. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please Share this page in order for us to reach our goal! 

We look forward to seeing you there.

story:
Our Organization

CY8ORG Design is an independent, art-centered company that started in Quito, Ecuador. Currently, our primary endeavor is producing small quantities of unique, quality clothing with original designs. We work with a professional seamstress to create the style of shirt we want, and use a process called heat-transfer sublimation to print hand-drawn or -painted designs onto the shirts. In this process, the ink fuses with polyester fibers in the shirt, making the design blend seamlessly with the fabric, avoiding the rubbery texture generally left by serigraphy, or screen-printing. Each design is used only a handful of times. What interests us is not mass-production, but quality and exclusivity. Our first production was received with lots of enthusiasm - both in Ecuador and in the United States. Only with a great deal of help from friends has it been possible to establish CY8ORG Design as a successful, independent clothing line - now we need to expand our community in order to expand our business, which is why we have created this campaign. 

Friends helped us with modeling and photography (above).

Working on a design for shirts (below).

Having gotten this far, we want to take the next step. We want to shift our focus to creative education and direct encouragement of the arts, rather than simple distribution. We have big dreams of growth in the future, including relocating to the Bellavista neighborhood in Santiago, Chile to open an educational, artistic, and (multi)cultural space. This space would include a gallery with art and original clothing on display and for sale, a simple café, book exchange, and a space to organize classes and events. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds in order to rent and equip such a space - for framing artwork, decorating, advertising, purchasing books, and providing materials to be used in art classes, as well as appliances and seating for the café.

If our goal of $15,000 is reached we could decorate and equip an amazing space for artists, students, and community members, but with just part of that we could do a lot. We would pursue alternative funding options, such as loans, to obtain everything necessary to create the planned space, and start work with whatever funds we obtain through this campaign.

For smaller donations, we also have electronic and paper copies of Kendra's autobiographical, bilingual, 30-page "graphic story", "Anagnorisis", a sort of prequel to CY8ORG Desgin. Our more expensive perks range from original prints and posters to one-of-a-kind shirts. The posters have been hand screenprinted by our designer/artist-in-residence, Kendra Lyons. The shirts are made by hand in Quito Ecuador by an independent seamstress, printed locally by a small business, and feature Kendra's original designs. Each is a unique combination of color, style, and design - a work of art in itself.

Torches of Freedom: Each design by CY8ORG contains a message, philosophy, or story. The design below was originally a screen-printed poster highlighting Edward Bernays, an important historical figure who, despite his enormous influence on the advertising industry, has been largely forgotten. Bernays, the nephew of Freud, used his uncle's ideas to sell products. He authored a book called "Propaganda" which inspired the Nazi propagandist Goebbels. This design tells the story of how Bernays, while working for Lucy Strike, single-handedly opened the tobacco market to women by paying debutants to walk in a suffrage march while smoking cigarettes, a very taboo practice for women at the time. A story about the incident was published by the local press under the title "Torches of Freedom", suggesting that cigarettes were phallic symbols of male power that could be "taken" by women, simply by smoking one. 

The Impact

So far, we have had immense success with the clothing we've produced. However, we want to do more - not just to distribute art, but to encourage creativity. Latin America is full of budding artists and movements, and we want to encourage and participate actively in this cultural revolution. The interest in the arts is there - but the infrastructure sometimes isn't. We want to provide a unique and diverse space that caters to the artistic and intellecutual needs of an artistic community, close to universities and museums in Santiago's Bellavista neighborhood, a growing hothouse of artistic activity. 

Helping some friends brighten up their new café (below). 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, but are interested in our project, you can really help us by sharing our campaign, and our company, with others.

story: .

Hi!

This is Kenyon Sky Dellecave. You may know me  from my involvement in such projects as the Dragon Lotus 2012 Colorado C.O.R.E., the One Eyed Monster, and most recently, Prima Materia. As you now know, I will be building the effigy for Apogaea this year. This will be a large and lengthy project, and I hope to involve many of you in its construction and design. While all of the materials for the construction of this piece will be fully paid for by the art grant I received, there were no funds in the grant for a workspace.

Denver is in need of more spaces where large projects can be built. I have begun leasing an arts space for not only this effigy project, but also for the Temple of Infinite Life, and a large metal sculpture, Arcus Hymenoptera. UNIT 3 Workspace is located at 5371 Tennyson st, UNIT 3. This will be a place for construction, workshops, art storage, and collaboration. I am creating a sustainable heavy arts space for the greater good of ourselves and for our larger community.

It is a personal imperative of mine to continue to make large, community built art, and by doing so, inspire and share skills with others so that they may lead a more creative, and thereby more fulfilled life.

I am asking for $2500 to cover the effigy's portion of renting a warehouse space for the four months of the effigy and temple build, and for some tools to facilitate the production of these and future projects. If any additional funds are raised, they will be used to further outfit the shop.

On offer are some one of a kind rewards that you won't be able to find anywhere else as gifts for your donations. Original artwork, custom screenprints, and a pizza party painting workshop are all being offered as rewards to contributors helping to make this dream of mine a reality. 

If I am unable to meet my fundraising goal, any money raised will go towards these exact goals. I am fully prepared to pay for the rental of the space once the effigy is finished, but I hope to be able to complete the effigy without incurring too many out of pocket expenses.

UNIT 3 Workspace will be an asset to our creative community here in Denver, providing a space to meet, work and collaborate with likeminded people. You may rest assured that your contribution will be used to fund the creation of more art, and to create a space for that to happen.

If you can't afford to contribute monetarily, there are other ways you can help:

You know that unused table saw in your garage, or that router you never use? We'll put it to good use here at UNIT 3. Any shelving, furniture, or building materials may be a useful donation as well.

Come and be a part of the creation of the effigy! This space is for us to get together and make art. To volunteer with the construction of the effigy, please join our Facebook group www.facebook.com/groups/totemeffigy/

Or give us a "like" here https://www.facebook.com/totemeffigy

If you're looking for space, either long or short term, please contact me directly kenyonsky@gmail.com

And please share this with all your friends.

I look forward to making more art with and for you!

Thank you!
story_txt: Hi!This is Kenyon Sky Dellecave. You may know me  from my involvement in such projects as the Dragon Lotus 2012 Colorado C.O.R.E., the One Eyed Monster, and most recently, Prima Materia. As you now know, I will be building the effigy for Apogaea this year. This will be a large and lengthy project, and I hope to involve many of you in its construction and design. While all of the materials for the construction of this piece will be fully paid for by the art grant I received, there were no funds in the grant for a workspace.Denver is in need of more spaces where large projects can be built. I have begun leasing an arts space for not only this effigy project, but also for the Temple of Infinite Life, and a large metal sculpture, Arcus Hymenoptera. story:
We are a group of eleven photographers graduating from the BS Photography program at the University of Central Florida, and we are producing a group exhibition of our senior thesis projects.  These photographs represent the culmination of four years of intensive study in the discipline of photography and we are excited to share our work with you!  Our selected space is Gallery 500 in Orlando, Florida and we will host a reception on April 26th from 5-7 PM for our friends and family to view our work and celebrate our achievement with us. 


The artists to be featured in the Bed of Roses Exhibit are:

Alyson Bowen
Kristen Colesanti
Heather Crane
MaKay Hartley
Davina Knowles
Alicia Lynn
Corryn Lytle
Katie McPherson
Ciara Ocasio
Ashley Roberts
Danielle Selbo

As a group we are responsible for the design and creation of all marketing materials, catalogs, displays, and the exhibition layout, as well as hosting our opening reception. For most of us, this is our first experience producing a full exhibition from the ground up. We want to design an exhibit that showcases our work in a way that reflects our professionalism and dedication to our art. 

Without adequate funding we will be unable to produce the polished and professional show that we believe our work demands.  Your contributions will aid us in printing promotional materials, including our exhibition catalog, as well as the materials needed to customize the gallery space to display our work the way we feel it deserves!  We will also be using a portion of the funds to provide refreshments to our family and friends as a thank you for attending the opening and supporting our careers as photographers.

Outside of indiegogo we are hosting photo booths and bake sales within our community to raise funding.

We would love to share our work with those who are unable to attend our opening and exhibition through our incentive items such as the calendar and signed prints. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute monetarily, you can still help by spreading the word to help make our show a success!


Bed of Roses Facebook Page

story:
Short Summary

My name is Yvonne Fly Onakeme Etaghene and I am a queer Nigerian woman, poet, dancer, actress and visual artist.  I've spent my life between the U.S. and Nigeria and because of this have often thought and made art about queer African identities and experiences.  GUAVA is a performance piece that will address queer African sexuality and how immigration and geographic location impact that.  GUAVA will document stories that are often ignored and marginalized and utilize art to share those stories as well as engage in conversations about queer African sexuality.  GUAVA will be performed in Nigeria and South Africa and will take place in partnership with LGBTQ African organizations.  Each performance will be accompanied by a workshop or community discussion that engages the political issues raised in the performance.  The intention of GUAVA is for queer Africans to share our own stories in our own words.  In addition, each community member present at a GUAVA performance/workshop will receive a free copy of "GUAVA: Poems & Workshops" (a collection of poetry & community engagement workshops.)  It is important that we document our work and share it and create our own herstories/histories.

I make this art and do this work because I do not know any other queer Nigerian poets performing these poems and saying these things in the ways that I am.  This work is necessary because I want to contribute to a global queer African community full of passionate warriors committed to speaking our truths and creating safe spaces for our lives to sparkle and flourish.

 

What We Need & What You Get

GUAVA needs $10,000 to accomplish the goals I have set forth.  The funds raised will go towards plane tickets, the GUAVA: Poems & Workshops (a collection of poetry & community engagement workshops), booking performance and rehearsal space, recording the video components of the performance piece and marketing materials.  All funds raised in excess of $10,000 will go towards expanding the African Tour of Guava.  If we don't make our goal, this project will most definitely still happen, just in fewer venues.

PERKS: I've lovingly chosen the perks with the same care and attention I would if I was making a care package.  It's fitting that so many perks are works of art I've created or will create because this project is about connecting with people via the incredibly powerful medium of art.  Crocheted earrings, crocheted infinity scarves, stickers, prints of my paintings, a writing workshop or performance of mine!  So much goodness!

The Loving Impact Of This Work

As I mentioned above, I don't know any other queer Nigerian women making art about the subject matters I do in the ways that I do.  It is important that we tell these stories because so much of how we understand and believe that we matter as human beings is by seeing ourselves reflected in the people around us, in the art around us, in the books, movies, communities around us.  The reason I am performing this work and traveling with it is because all of us deserve to know that our stories matter and are beautiful.

 

FREE Ways You Can Support This Work

  • Please help spread the word!  Tweet about it, share it on Faebook, email folks about it.  If you are moved by this campaign, please TELL SOMEONE ABOUT IT.
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the good word!

 

Questions?  Comments?  Ideas?  Please share them with me: myloveisaverb [at] gmail [dot] com

Thank you, thank you, thank you!

 

Lots of Nigerian Dyke Love,

~Etaghene

 

BIO: Yvonne Fly Onakeme Etaghene is an Ijaw and Urhobo Nigerian dyke performance activist, poet, dancer, essayist, playwright, actress, video blogger and mixed media visual artist who was born with a mouth full of dynamite and sugarcane. She uses her poetry to chisel a verbal sculpture of her soul for listeners while addressing issues of race, ethnicity, class, gender, sexuality, war, imperialism, love, self-esteem and family. Etaghene has self-published three collections of poetry, toured nationally and performed in over 30 u.s. cities. She was interviewed by and was a Contributing Writer to None on Record: Stories of Queer Africa, a sound documentary project that collects the stories of QLGBT Africans from the African Continent and the Diaspora. She has toured nationally with her multi-media one-woman show, Volcano's Birthright{s}.  Etaghene is a mixed-media visual artist who has produced 4 solo art exhibitions.  Etaghene has written and directed 2 poem videos (“The First Time” [2010] and “i deserve somebody” [2011]) that marry film, poetry and music.  Etaghene has self-published 3 chapbooks of poetry: afrocrown: fierce poetry (2000), write or die (2004) and tongue twisted transcontinental sista (2006.)  She independently released an album of poetry and music entitled liberty avenue, nigeria, usa (2004.)   She has shared stages with Amina Baraka, Bonfire Madigan, Sharon Bridgforth, Staceyann Chin, climbing poeTree, Invincible, DJ Kuttin Kandi, Lenelle Moïse, DJ Moni, Queen GodIs, Ongina Ryan, Hanifah Walidah & innumerable other brilliant magic-makers.

story:
**$10, $20 or $50 from you means $20, $40, or $100 to help SIFC accomplish BIG things!**

Clarion New Media is sponsoring the SIFC Chicago Media Match Drive, where they will match any amount of donations to SIFC for an amount up to $1,500--meaning if we make our goal of $1,500, they will give us $1,500, giving us a total of $3,000 to update our team's media equipment and help us file for non-profit status!


What is SIFC anyway? Sixty Inches From Center: Chicago Arts Archive and Collective Project (SIFC) is an organization that documents and displays online the art that exists outside the “center”. We at Sixty Inches From Center are not trying to reinvent the wheel. We are looking for ways to strengthen the arts programs, artist collaboratives and creative practices or spaces that already exist and bring together the many different underground organizations, artists and collectives that are doing amazing things. Our goal is to create new bridges and act as facilitators of collaboration in Chicago’s art scene.

This is a Media Match Drive. What's that?  Now that Chicago Artist Month, one of the busiest art months of the year, has come to a close and we have officially launched the website, it is on with the next line of projects for us at SIFC. It came to our knowledge about a week ago that our media and marketing advisor’s company Clarion New Media wants to sponsor us for a short campaign. Our last campaign was set out to raise funds that will help supplement our media needs concerning new equipment and we only got a small fraction of our goal. Clarion New Media fully recognizes how important our project is to the Chicago arts community after working with us since we first approached them last spring with our idea.  Clarion New Media believes in our mission and to encourage others to participate that they will match every dollar amount donated up to $1,500 dollars for our next campaign.  The funds raised will be used to purchase the equipment that we so desperately need so we can function in a more efficient, visually appealing and professional manor.  Clarion New Media has already donated their time in developing our new website, producing videos and training our staff to produce and publish engaging content.

What will these funds be used for? We need things such as Sanyo VPC-CG20 Dual HD 10MP Camcorders, DSLR NEX-5 cameras and Olympus WS 400S 1 GB Digital voice recorders for our team. In order for these items to function correctly, we need other things such as memory cards, external hard drives, memory card readers, hardware updates, and software updates.  We are also filing for our non-profit status, so some of the funds will contribute to making that happen.

Together we can make this happen!  We are very appreciative for this opportunity to raise double our goal of  $1,500. And all we need to reach this number is a minimum of 150 donations at $10 dollars or 75 donations at $20. If you feel exceptionally generous all donations over $100 will receive special recognition on our website with donor status along with an associated website link.  For those who are willing to donate amounts under $100, please keep in mind what your contribution is allowing us at SIFC to accomplish. Our efforts bring under publicized art of Chicago to the world. Make the match and help Sixty Inches From Center reach our goal!


How else can you help?  Spread the word to art lovers and Chicagoans.  Tell a friend!  Tell an artist!  Bring it up at Thanksgiving dinner!  And visit us and Clarion New Media online:

www.sixtyinchesfromcenter.org

Facebook: SIFC Chicago

www.clarionnewmedia.com

story:
Salutations!

My name is David and I am a designer hailing from Portland, Oregon.

I started this campaign to raise some funding for Christmas gifts for four awesome kids.  This is the minimum amount I'd like to raise in this campaign.

Even $1, $5, $10 contributions will help.  You can select to just contribute instead of buying any of the perks.  Speaking of...

Here are the PERKS

I have this design piece, 'BOOMBOX WARRIOR PRIESTESS' that I'd like to share. It will be reproduced in 3 different forms:

  1. 24" x 24" SERIGRAPH PRINT - LIMITED RUN of 100, hand numbered and signed, printed on black archival paper, $20 ea.
  2. T-SHIRT - LIMITED RUN of 100, 100% cotton, different sizes and cuts available (you can specify when the campaign is over), $20 ea.
  3. 47.5" LONGBOARD DECK - LIMITED RUN of 100, 7-ply laminate, high quality production, top and bottom graphics, $95 ea. 

Boombox Warrior Priestess 24" x 24" SERIGRAPH PRINT 
LIMITED RUN of 100, hand numbered and signed, printed on black archival paper, $20 ea.

Boombox Warrior Priestess T-SHIRT 
LIMITED RUN of 100, 100% cotton, different sizes and guy/girl cuts available, $20 ea.


Boombox Warrior Priestess 47.5" LONGBOARD DECK
LIMITED RUN of 100, 7-ply laminate, high quality production, bottom and top graphics (respectively), $95 ea. 

The Impact

Your contribution will help some sweet kids have a good Christmas. 

If you have any questions or comments, feel free to contact me!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute and that's perfectly fine as it is the holidays so budgets might be tight or otherwise, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help....

If you like what you see then share with your friends on Facebook or other social media!  Indiegogo has some cool share tools to get the word out.

Thank you for taking the time to check this out and Merry Christmas / Happy Holidays!
