story:
Short Summary

Help us fund Uganda's first ever public camera obscura!!!

We are a trio of Kampala based visual artists/filmmakers who will be exhibiting Uganda's first camera obscura at the 7th LaBa Art Festival (25th May, 2013). The theme for this year's festival is "Open Studio", where artists are supposed to present their work an show the process of production". We came with the idea to construct a camera obscura which would both entertain and show the science behind what we do in its most basic sense.

We are naming the camera obscura 'Strange Fruit' as there will be two actors hanging upside down on the outside of the studio, which will create an inverted image of their hair standing on end on the inside of the camera. The name is also a twist on the Billie Holiday song of the same name, in which she used the metaphor to describe the lynchings of african-americans. This time we are using the metaphor in a more playful manner.

Why we need your contributions?

We are looking to raise 501 US dollars which will go towards:

  • Construction of dark room
  • Construction of monkey bars installation
  • Actors, paint and make-up

 

 

Who we are?

Eric Mukalazi is a self-taught visual artist from Kampala. His practice generally utilises the mediums of film, photography and animation. His work explores themes of modern Ugandan identities through; hip hop, fashion, sub cultures and youth. Mukalazi was one of twelve artists that exhibited at the first KLA Contemporary Art Festival in 2012 with his 3D animation ‘Breezy Nuts’. He is currently undergoing a residency at 32º East | Ugandan Arts Trust.

 

Alex Lyons is a visual artist from London that currently lives and works in Kampala. He trained in ‘Film & TV’ at the University of the Arts London where he worked on a number of documentaries and dramas as well as exploring video art and photography. His work is exhibited in an experimental manner, which is designed so that he can observe the human interaction with his films. Lyons has been involved in a number of group exhibitions in London, Paris and Madrid before coming to Uganda to undertake a residency and mentorship scheme at 32º East | Ugandan Arts Trust.

 

Mugeni Mukanga has been an Artistic Director at Dragonfly Media since 2008. Under Dragonfly Media, he has worked in close collaboration with Eric Mukalazi and Alex Lyons of 32 Degrees East by providing research, technical assistance and artistic direction on several projects including; Breezy Nuts (KLA ART 2012), Power (Baboon Forest, 2012), Criminal Swag (Young Zee/Swangz Avenue, 2012) Chart Dimensions (Recycling Materials, Thomas Aquilina. RIBA Scholarship, 2012) among others. Dragonfly Media are currently in pre-production of the highly anticipated Cowboys of Kampala
story_txt:
Short Summary
Help us fund Uganda's first ever public camera obscura!!!
We are a trio of Kampala based visual artists/filmmakers who will be exhibiting Uganda's first camera obscura at the 7th LaBa Art Festival (25th May, 2013). The theme for this year's festival is "Open Studio", where artists are supposed to present their work an show the process of production". We came with the idea to construct a camera obscura which would both entertain and show the science behind what we do in its most basic sense.
We are naming the camera obscura 'Strange Fruit' as there will be two actors hanging upside down on the outside of the studio, which will create an inverted image of their hair standing on end on the inside of the camera. The name is also a twist on the Billie Holiday song of the same name, in which she used the metaphor to describe the lynchings of african-americans. This time we are using the metaphor in a more playful manner.
Why we need your contributions?
We are looking to raise 501 US dollars which will go towards:

Construction of dark room
Construction of monkey bars installation
Actors, paint and make-up
 
 
Who we are?
Eric Mukalazi is a self-taught visual artist from Kampala. His practice generally utilises the mediums of film, photography and animation. His work explores themes of modern Ugandan identities through; hip hop, fashion, sub cultures and youth. Mukalazi was one of twelve artists that exhibited at the first KLA Contemporary Art Festival in 2012 with his 3D animation ‘Breezy Nuts’. He is currently undergoing a residency at 32º East | Ugandan Arts Trust.
 
Alex Lyons is a visual artist from London that currently lives and works in Kampala. He trained in ‘Film & TV’ at the University of the Arts London where he worked on a number of documentaries and dramas as well as exploring video art and photography. His work is exhibited in an experimental manner, which is designed so that he can observe the human interaction with his films. Lyons has been involved in a number of group exhibitions in London, Paris and Madrid before coming to Uganda to undertake a residency and mentorship scheme at 32º East | Ugandan Arts Trust.
 
Mugeni Mukanga has been an Artistic Director at Dragonfly Media since 2008. Under Dragonfly Media, he has worked in close collaboration with Eric Mukalazi and Alex Lyons of 32 Degrees East by providing research, technical assistance and artistic direction on several projects including; Breezy Nuts (KLA ART 2012), Power (Baboon Forest, 2012), Criminal Swag (Young Zee/Swangz Avenue, 2012) Chart Dimensions (Recycling Materials, Thomas Aquilina. RIBA Scholarship, 2012) among others. Dragonfly Media are currently in pre-production of the highly anticipated Cowboys of Kampala

story:
Hello!

I’m an emerging artist in Portland, Oregon. After receiving my studio art degree in Asheville, NC, I had the opportunity to spend time at Penland School of Crafts as a studio assistant. The artist I worked with suggested that I explore myself and community through residency as a way to discovery in my art practice. I’m taking her advice!

I have been accepted as an artist-in-residence at the Abetenim Arts Village near the city of Kumasi in Ghana for  November 2013 through the non-profit organization NKA Foundation. As a resident, I will learn West African dance in the Ashanti region with community members and incorporate that dance into a landscape related video project. 

Art and travel shifts perspective for me immensely. Not only will I meet new people and dance, but I hope to create something that will lay the groundwork for others to have a perspective shift as well. The NKA Foundation brings international artists to a rural community so that we can share our experiences with each other and grow. I am responsible for raising 100% of the funds for this amazing experience. 

I could do this for $3,000. Here’s where the money will go:

$1,500 airfare, $300 lodging/food costs, $600 vaccinations/visa, $600 fees/supplies

Any and all support is most appreciated! Not only will you have my absolute appreciation, but you will also receive different perks that range from a personal, hand-written postcard from Africa to producer credit in the final video with a public thanks from NKA Foundation. Everyone who contributes will be included by name in a thank you on my blog. 

Please spread the word! You’re awesome. Thank you!

Let’s dance,

Erin Fussell

http://nkafoundation.org

http://erinfussell.com

story:
This is a Kickstarter that I've made to help our friends and ourselves.

Our goal is to reach $2000.

The money is going to be divided into a few categories of what we need.

Our friend Jitters is having car troubles and really needs money to help him out, so part of it is going to him.

The next part is going to Ensayne and I's travelling and whatever other costs we have to get to a stable home.

Another part is going to another friend that needs some help.

The last bit will go into the development of the project rewards I'm offering.

When we reach $1000, I'll make a rpgmaker horror game that'll be for everyone to play. After the kickstarter ends, I'll have a vote for exactly what kind of Horror it'll be.

One of the choices is The White Mice which is a horror/sci-fi about a kid who goes to a Private School and learns that it's not what it seems.

When we reach our final goal of $2000 I'll make a full 30 minute episode of Corrupted Twilight with custom music/song and voice acting from myself and other people.

Meanwhile, the donations will give you things like drawings by Sin and cameos for the game and Corrupted Twilight animation.

If we do surpass our goal and reach $3000, I will do another game that'll be of Corrupted Twilight going to other worlds with her vortex manipulator, it'll probably be a puzzle/action game.

If we do not reach our goal, we will be keeping the money as you'll be getting things for your donations and we do need the money urgently. If we do not reach the Game goal at least, the ones who donated to be cameo'd will be cameo'd in my blogs such as Corrupted Twilight and Skypainter-Sin.

Thanks for listening and we appreciate any help you can give us!

story:
Update

Thank you to everyone who has contributed to this campaign. I’m thrilled to announce that I have reached my goal early. If you contributed — THANK YOU! Your support means a lot to me. 

Because the campaign is active until November 30, you can still get your holiday greeting cards, or any of the other perks, through me via this campaign.

Further proceeds will be used to cover the following expenses:

1.  An additional $2,000 (for a total goal of $7,000) will cover the printing costs of the greeting cards.

2.  An additional $500 (total goal $7,500) would cover the Indiegogo, Paypal and postage expenses, and allow me to use all of the contributions towards my residency.

3.  Finally, if I can raise an additional $2,000.00 (total goal $9,500), I would have the funds to extend my stay at the residency for an additional month. The additional time would be ideal to further develop my large-format drawings. I would apply to extend my stay at the residency, if it is looking like a possibility through the campaign and from amazing support of the contributors.

Please note: I have added an additional perk to the campaign: Santa’s (very happy) Helper. Thank you so much!!!


The Big Idea

My name is Angela Gooliaff and I’m an emerging visual artist living in Vancouver, BC, Canada. I have a passion for telling stories, especially stories about tiny but fascinating creatures among us – bugs!

My favourite subject to draw is ants. And I hope these ants will take me all the way to France. Why ants? Because they are admirable and multi-dimensional little beings. No one works harder than an ant. In my greeting cards, I have also expanded to other interesting and beautiful bugs such as British Columbia’s Rugose stag beetle, a Blue Morpho butterfly, ladybugs, dragonflies and others. 

My goal is to raise $5,000.00 to attend DRAWinternational, an artist residency program in Caylus, France.  DRAWinternational provides illustrators a one-month opportunity to focus entirely on their artwork, expanding their ideas and creativity, and collaborate with other like-minded artists. I am honoured to have received acceptance to this program.

I have a Bachelor of Science, majoring in Biology with a Psychology minor, along with a Bachelor of Fine Arts from Emily Carr University.

What You Can Purchase

Christmas is just around the corner! Are you ready? My goal is to have you prepared for the festive season with my unique insect-inspired holiday season cards. My services offered are as follows (look to the right-hand side of this website for more details):

$10 – two unique insect-inspired Christmas gift cards of your choice. One with a handwritten message from me and the other for you to share.

$25 – five insect-inspired Christmas cards of your choice to spread holiday cheer to your friends and family.

$60 – 12 insect-inspired Christmas cards of your choice, plus you’ll receive a surprise from me in July! 

$100 – 20 buggy Christmas cards of your choice, plus a greeting card surprise from France and a signed black & white bug sketch.

$250 – Got a favourite bug? I’ll draw it for you in colour. You will receive the original signed copy and paper size approximately 8” x 8”.

$400 – Original and elegant drawings depicting a line of hard-working ants marching single file from each paper's edge. The drawings measuring 62” l x 14" w rolled in a scroll with a red ribbon. Each ant is hand drawn with pencil on Japanese paper. To view drawings, please visit my blog.

$500 – For Vancouver-area residents only, a four-hour drawing class with me. Invite some friends and let’s have fun! This class is great for small school groups of up to 5 students.

How You Can Help

This unique overseas residency will be made possible through your generous contributions.  With your support, I will be able to continue developing as an artist and be able to bring forward new ideas and creations in the future.

In return, I will provide creative and unique Christmas cards that are original and locally-made novel artwork to help connect you to those special people in your life this holiday season.

My Ultimate Goal

All proceeds from this campaign will be used towards funding my residency in France at DRAWinternational, in June of 2014.  How the funds will be allocated:

  • $3,000 per DRAWinternational's room and board fees after exchange conversion
  • $1,500 will go to travel costs
  • $500 will towards materials
  • $450 will go to Indiegogo for their fees

Thank you!

Thank you so much for your support! Your contribution, whether in the form of a donation to the campaign or sharing the message with your family and friends, is truly appreciated. It’s through sharing that the campaign will be successful.

FAQs

When will I receive my greeting cards?

My goal is to ship them as soon as I receive your order. Orders are shipped within 48 hours. Should unforeseen circumstances occur and there is a delay, I will be sure to contact you to advise.

Does the shipping fee get automatically charged to me through PayPal?

No. This is because your shipping costs depend on where you live. Please add the shipping charge on top of the cost of your chosen package. If you live in Vancouver and I know you, we can work out an alternate arrangement.

How do I find out more about the artist?

You can visit me online at www.angelagooliaff.com. You can also follow me on twitter  and facebook where I post frequently about my artistic adventures.

story:
Hello, my name is LaVonne Sallee’. I was born in Roswell, New Mexico and was one year old when the aliens landed. Rumor has it that when the aliens died they occupied the bodies of the babies in the area. Some say that is where I get my artistic talents and humor.

After becoming disabled, I took early retirement from the corporate world where I had been a criminal investigator. My career enabled me to raise three children, but I never attended to my true calling and passion with my artistic talents. Who would have thought, at the age of 60, my life would start over and turn in a whole new direction.

Coping with depression from my disability, on one of my many visits to the doctor, I passed an art gallery that was showing Altered Barbie Art Work. I spent over an hour examining the work. I talked to the curator who explained that she had asked 50 of her artist friends to create a piece of art work with Barbie as the central character.  Immediately, I was intrigued to explore this as a medium.

I wondered if I could sell this artwork but worried about copyright law. I did research online and confirmed that I would not be in violation as this work is parody.

 

While raising children, I always shopped thrift stores, garage sales and flea markets looking for treasures and bargains. The idea of shopping for props and putting those recycled props with Barbie (sliced and diced, drawn and quartered) inspired me and I began to create One Of A Kind (OOAK) Barbie Art. I started in August 2006 and to date, have created 300 pieces that run the whole gamut of experiences, conditions, fetishes and surreal expressions. 

I’ve received a lot of amazing press in these short 5 years. There have been articles about my work in 8 newspapers in the San Francisco Bay Area and Reuters, I was interviewed on two television talk shows (Sacramento and Vallejo), a radio program (Berkeley, Ca.) and a special interest piece featured on CBS news (San Francisco) along with a Wikipedia entry.

I have a live and work space downtown Vallejo California. According to Newsweek Magazine (Feb. 2011), Vallejo is the second most dying city in the United States next to New Orleans. Last year I averaged just under $20 a week (gross) in sales in Vallejo. While my work is greatly appreciated locally, Vallejo is well known for its dire economy. The downtown area where I show my work is a ghost town. There is more than a 60% vacancy rate and very little foot traffic.

For the last six months my focus has been on building a social network and increasing my online presence. (Blog; Facebook; Tumblr; Linkedin)  While business is growing I miss the interaction with the public.  A common response to my work is; “I have never seen anything like this before. Are there other artists who do this kind of work?” One of the things I love most about showing my work is that it is entertaining and makes people laugh out loud.

Last year, the ‘Nada Dada Ding Dong’ (http://www.nadadadadingdong.net) event had over 5,000 visitors from across the United States and various parts of the world and was written up in the New York Times. I have not participated in too many venues that require me to pack and unpack, lift and move because of my disability but I have someone who is willing to take this trip with me and assist me.

I am asking for your assistance to raise $3,500 (which will allow me to take the next step and reach beyond the boundaries of Vallejo, California……....) for travel, shipment, accommodations and other expenses, for the Nada Dada Ding Dong event.

 

LaVonne Sallee', Artist

story:
Hello, My name is Michael Thayer and I am a photographer from Grand  Rapids Michigan.  I have entered Artprize 2012 with my work titled "Her name is Anonymous"  This is a collection of five 20x30 photographs dealing with the themes of anonymity and sensuality.  

 

For those who don't know, Artprize is a major art competition in Grand Rapids that is now in it's 4th year. This year's competition has more than 1500 entries, and is judged by public voting, as well as juried awards with prizes totaling over $500,00.00   More info on Artprize can be found here:  www.artprize.org

 

This is my first year entering Artprize, and I want to make a good showing.  I am asking for donors to help me with the cost of having the prints and support materials made.

 

I am going to have the prints made at 20x30 inches mounted on 1 inch black foam core.  This will make for a large, visually stunning presentation.

 

The support materials will be business cards, and promo cards with information about the work, and my artist voting number

story:
The Rhythmic Arts Project is a nonprofit organization working successfully in the field of Intellectual and Developmental Differences for more than 14 years. We work with Children and Adults alike and do everything possible to help them succeed in the typical world. We strive to include them in every aspect of life through an innovative methodology using musical notation and percussion to address reading, writing and arithmetic.

People with Down Syndrome, Autism and various other developmental disabilities want the same things in life as we do, to be appreciated for their accomplishments, to contribute to society, to work in the real world, to love and to be loved and most importantly, to belong.

On September 28, 2012 at the Lobero Theatre in Santa Barbara, California, the annual TRAP Benefit Concert will be held. 

This funding campaign will help us to pay for the production of the concert's poster artwork so generously created by Rock Concert poster legend Bob Masse.  The funding will go towards artwork, printing costs, shipping as well as concert poster t-shirts.  Additional funds will go towards enhancing TRAP's ability to empower more children and adults to succeed in the typical world.  

Our target is $5,000.00

This artwork is one of a kind and, depending on which Kit you select, will be signed by the artist as well as by TRAP Board Members Edward James Olmos (Battlestar Galactica) and John Densmore (The Doors).

The perks also include attending and hanging out with some pretty amazing musicians at The Lobero Theatre in Santa Barbara on September 28th as well as pictures with the artists and more signatures by everyone in the show!

If you live too far away to attend the benefit, there are several Kit options to allow you to enjoy the great Bob Masse artwork as well as support the mission of TRAP.

The proceeds raised will enhance our ability to fund classes in Special Education and to enlist others in our Train the Trainer programs.

On a personal note, this work has become a way of life for me, a richer and more rewarding life in every way. The next time you see a person with a developmental disability, stop and say hello! You might be pleasantly surprised and you might very well make a new friend, a good one.

With gratitude and respect,

Eddie Tuduri / Founder The Rhythmic Arts Project

http://www.traponline.org

The Rhythmic Arts Project Benefit Concert Details:

Bonnie Bramlett, Tata Vega, Rosemary Butler and Carl Graves with Special Guests from LITTLE FEAT Paul Barrere and Fred Tackett.

Hosted by Edward James Olmos

Friday, September 28th, 2012
Lobero Theatre
Santa Barbara, CA 93101

8:00 PM

Tickets on sale AUGUST 1, 2012 at: http://www.lobero.com/events/rhythmic-arts-proj...
or
Lobero Theatre Box Office

We strive to include them in every aspect of life through an innovative methodology using musical notation and percussion to address reading, writing and arithmetic.
People with Down Syndrome, Autism and various other developmental disabilities want the same things in life as we do, to be appreciated for their accomplishments, to contribute to society, to work in the real world, to love and to be loved and most importantly, to belong.
On September 28, 2012 at the Lobero Theatre in Santa Barbara, California, the annual TRAP Benefit Concert will be held. 
This funding campaign will help us to pay for the production of the concert's poster artwork so generously created by Rock Concert poster legend Bob Masse.  The funding will go towards artwork, printing costs, shipping as well as concert poster t-shirts.  Additional funds will go towards enhancing TRAP's ability to empower more children and adults to succeed in the typical world.  
Our target is $5,000.00
This artwork is one of a kind and, depending on which Kit you select, will be signed by the artist as well as by TRAP Board Members Edward James Olmos (Battlestar Galactica) and John Densmore (The Doors).
The perks also include attending and hanging out with some pretty amazing musicians at The Lobero Theatre in Santa Barbara on September 28th as well as pictures with the artists and more signatures by everyone in the show!
If you live too far away to attend the benefit, there are several Kit options to allow you to enjoy the great Bob Masse artwork as well as support the mission of TRAP.
The proceeds raised will enhance our ability to fund classes in Special Education and to enlist others in our Train the Trainer programs.
On a personal note, this work has become a way of life for me, a richer and more rewarding life in every way. The next time you see a person with a developmental disability, stop and say hello! You might be pleasantly surprised and you might very well make a new friend, a good one.
With gratitude and respect,
Eddie Tuduri / Founder The Rhythmic Arts Project
http://www.traponline.org
The Rhythmic Arts Project Benefit Concert Details:
Bonnie Bramlett, Tata Vega, Rosemary Butler and Carl Graves with Special Guests from LITTLE FEAT Paul Barrere and Fred Tackett.Hosted by Edward James OlmosFriday, September 28th, 2012Lobero TheatreSanta Barbara, CA 931018:00 PMTickets on sale AUGUST 1, 2012 at: http://www.lobero.com/events/rhythmic-arts-proj...orLobero Theatre Box Office

story:
If I Should Die and Go To Hell

A collection of original dark poetry and Gothic Victorian photography

If I should die and go to Hell

Would you build a Taj Mahal

To house my soul and keep it safe

From the worries of these troubled days?


If I Should Die and Go To Hell is a collection of dark poetry celebrating life, death, and the night, placed alongside genuine Gothic Victorian photography and memento mori (photographic keepsakes of the dead).

These emotional, touching, poignant, and sometimes humourous poems are written by author Paul Voodini (Victorian Academy of Magick, Vampire Survivors) with guest contributions from Eddie Burgos English, Saturnine Nepenthe, and Claire Wall. When combined with the equally touching and poignant photographs they provide a powerful experience for the reader.

IF I DIE FIRST

Dark the clouds that formed above our house as you slipped away
Rainy was the day, forlorn and lost and grey
And as the undertaker took your lifeless body away
I remembered the little jokes and how I'd laugh when you'd say
"If I die first I'm coming back to haunt you."
As I go to bed this evening all I've got to say
Is please don't. Please don't haunt me. Please just keep away.

No dull thud upon the door or upon the window pane
To make me spill my cocoa when my soul you come to claim
No moaning or shrieking or calling out my name
It's not funny anymore and the house is too dark to play that game
"If I die first I'm coming back to haunt you."
Please don't play little jokes on me, please if it's all the same
You know they wouldn't believe me. They would all think me insane.

MISTAKEN IDENTITY

I carried flowers to the graveyard
I came to say goodbye
But the roads are long, the day is short
And the flowers have all died.

I carried flowers to the graveyard
And I looked to find your name
But the paths are long, the night is short
And the graves all look the same.

I carried flowers to the graveyard
And walked the whole night through
I found the grave and realised
It was me who died, not you.

The poems and photographs will be presented together for the first time ever, and you will be able to receive either a paperback or hardback edition by supporting this project.

ON BEING BURIED ALIVE

I wasn't dead when they buried me
Oh woe! Oh woe! Oh woe!
And no-one now can hear poor me
Oh no! Oh no! Oh no!
Though I scream and scratch and tear at my hair
They've all gone home, there's no-one there.

I was not dead, merely in a faint
How sad! How sad! How sad!
And so I swore at Christ and his saints
'Tis Bad! 'Tis bad! 'Tis bad!
They'll dig me up in a hundred years and put me on display
And school children will in nightmares dream of dying this awful way

But for me it is reality
The dark the fear the screams
I choked to death, there was no air
I pulled out my nails and I pulled out my hair
And in the minutes it took to die
I ripped out my tongue and poked out my eyes
I went quite mad in such distress
I broke my legs and soiled my dress

Oh woe. Oh woe.
Oh woe.

This beautiful collection will be something you will cherish and savour for many years to come - a poignant, exquisite reminder of our own mortality and the Gothic side of life. Even in life, we are but one heartbeat from death.

The author and project manager is Paul Voodini, a professional author and writer from the UK. He manages the Vampire Survivors Facebook page at www.facebook.com/VampireSurvivors as well as writing both works of fiction and instructional books for magicians. 

It is hoped that the books will be printed and ready for distribution in time for Halloween. If you're thinking of buying for a gift, this book would make a delightfully dark Christmas gift for the Gothic-inclined person in your life! 

The book features approximately 50 poems and 50 photographs.

story:
The project

The 4 crown project is a special project for me. I was thinking already longer to start this project. And now I start the project. Around the world there are not many good quality replica crowns. And especially not crowns you can rent! The original crowns are of course not to rent for anybody. The Dutch crown is normal locked up. And the three English crowns don’t leave the Tower of London. With this project I can make many dreams come true!

How will it be if you have a special party and you have this four amazing crowns on your party! Everyone will be jealous on you. How does he/she come to this 4 amazing crowns! You can’t even see by yourself the difference between the original or the replica. This is just one example where you can hire the crowns for! There are many other examples.

Before I could start the project I was searching what for kind of materials I want to use. And what is possible. I get advice from different silversmith’s. And they gived me good advice. After the advice I start searching on the internet for the materials. Is it possible how I want to make the crowns? And now I finished that part of the research. And yes it’s possible!

After the research I need a company that could help me with my project. On the start it wasn’t easy to find a company. But on 30-04-2013 we get in the Netherlands a new King. And they talked a lot about the crown and the company that made the crown for King Willem II. So I contact that company and they replied me they want to help me with this interesting project. The company name is: Bonebakker (based in Amsterdam http://www.bonebakker.nl/en). They made in 1840 the original crown from King Willem II.

The official draw of the crown for King Willem II in 1840 made by Bonebakker.

 

So now I know what for kind of materials I want to use. And I found a company that can help me. So I can start with my project! I made this page on Indiegogo to start my project. Of course I hope you all will support me to finish this great project and I can make the four high quality crowns.

 

The Company

After this four crowns are made what I want to do with the four crowns? After this crowns are made I want to start my own business in it. At the start I want to exhibite the crowns for a short time on different locations. After the exhibite people can rent the crowns from me. And I want to exhibite them on special events. When the crowns not be rented they will be showed in glasses showcases. There will also become a site where I will put all the information on when the crowns are made. People can see there all the rent information and what for special events I want to do. Will there be a market for renting the crowns? Yes there is! I researched a long time if there is a market for renting. I saw a lot of people that searched for crowns like this but they can’t find good quality crowns for renting.

 

The crowns

To make this crowns is an very expensive job. The crowns will be made with the best quality materials there are. When we reached the first goal we will start with the first crown.

Goal 1: The Dutch crown

The Dutch crown will be made with copper. On the copper we will put a chromium layer. And that will be gold-plated. For the glass stones in the original crown we will use synthetic stones. We use the synthetic stones to make the perfect look. For the pearls we use high quality imitation pearls. We do that because real pears are too expensive for it. We use this materials because this are the best materials to make the high quality replica crowns.

Goal 2: The Queen Mother’s crown

The Queen Mother’s crown will be made with copper. On the copper we will put a chromium layer. And that will be platinum-plated. For the diamonds in the original crown we will use synthetic stones. We use the synthetic stones too make the perfect look. For the ermine band we use imitation ermine. Because that’s more animal friendly. We use this materials because this are the best materials to make the high quality replica crowns.

Goal 3: St. Edward’s crown

The St. Edward’s crown will be made with copper. On the copper we will put a chromium layer. And that will be gold-plated. For the gems and diamonds in the original crown we will use synthetic stones. We use the synthetic stones to make the perfect look.  For the golden beads in the original crown we use gold-plated beads. We use the golden-plated beads too make the perfect look. For the ermine band we use imitation ermine. Because that’s more animal friendly. (In this crown they used also a bit platinum we will use that also to make it perfect.) We use this materials because this are the best materials to make the high quality replica crowns.

Goal 4: The Imperial State crown

The Imperial State crown will be made with copper. On the copper we will put a chromium layer. And that will be platinum-plated.  For the gems and diamonds in the original crown we will use synthetic stones. We use the synthetic stones to make the perfect look.  For the pearls we use high quality imitation pearls. We do that because real pears are too expensive for it. . For the ermine band we use imitation ermine. Because that’s more animal friendly. (In this crown they used also a bit gold & silver we will use that also to make it perfect.) We use this materials because this are the best materials to make the high quality replica crowns.

 

I need your help

Without your help I can’t make the high quality replica crowns. This means:

  • I can’t make my dream project come true.
  • I can’t make the crowns.
  • I can’t start my own business.
  • Other people can’t have pleasure from the good looking crowns.

By backing me now, you will help me to make my dream project come true! And more special I will be the first person that can let you rent the Dutch crown! I will go to special events to show people the great look of the special crowns! So you will not only helping me but you give also a big pleasure to a lot of people.

 

Where will your funding go?

All the donations goes straight to the crowns. We need all the money for:

  • The materials – We need a lot of materials for every crown so that will already be very expensive.
  • The silversmith – He make the crowns for me. I can’t make the crowns on my own.
  • Indiegogo fee – We need to pay a small fee to Indiegogo.

 

Use of funds

To make the dream project come true I need your help. I made an easy goals list where you can see how much I need for every crown. (The money behind the crown is just for 1 crown.)

 

What will I do if I not reach my goal?

Get me to €20.000,- and I can make the great replica of the Dutch crown.

Get me to the next €30.000,- and I can make the great replica of the Queen Mother’s crown.

Get me to the next €30.000,- and I can make the great replica of the St. Edward’s crown.

Get me to the next €30.000,- and I can make the great replica of the Imperial State crown.

If I don’t reach the next goal I need don’t worry! I safe the money for later. If I can’t make all the four crowns when the days for the project are over. I will make an following project. And I safe the money I already have for the first goal I want to reach with the following project. Till I get the for crowns.

 

The perks

When you will help me to make my dream project come true you can choose one of the perks. This is what you get in exchange for your help. You can see the perks on the right side from this page.

Like you can see I will do a lottery. This lottery will only become reality if we reached all the 4 goals. After the 3th goal will be reached I will make a update where you all can see what the prices will be for the lottery. And I am sure you will have more like 1 ticket for it!

 

The €35,- perk is the very special Limited Edition perk. Just 50 people van get this perk! Be fast before you are to late! The e-mail will be send from the same e-mail adress like all other e-mails. The e-mail is real from the Prince of Nottingham. He will give you a special 'Thank you' for a great contribute at this project.

 

Special Thank you!

I will add the first 10 contributors here on the site from Indiegogo! You want your name down here? Be fast before you are number 11!

1. M & P & J

2.

3.

4.

5.

6.

7.

8.

9.

10.

* If you choose to be anonymous I add only your begin letter.

 

Other support

You can support me on different ways. It would be great if you can make a donation for my project. You can also support me to like me here, tell it to friend on Facebook. I made special for this project an Facebook page. Thank you very much for all your support!

 

Updates

For now I hope I gave you a good look about my project and I hope you are as excited about the project as i am! I hope you will support me with my project. I will thank you already very much. I will update you all here on Indiegogo and on the Facebook page. So I hope you will come back sometimes to check the project. Thank you very much and enjoy the project.

 

FACs

1. Why are the English crowns more expencive to make like the Dutch crown?

A: For the english crowns we need more materials. They used in the English crowns more gems and other materials like in the Dutch crown.

2. What are synthetic stones?

A: Synthetic stones are human made stones. They become from a laboratory.

3. Why this materials and not cheaper materials?

A: If I use cheaper materials the crowns will not get the perfect looking replica like I want to create. The synthetic stones have the perfect size from the original gems. And the other materials are selected to give the crowns the perfect look so it would looks like you see the real crowns.

4. What will happened with the crowns after they are made?

A: At the start I want to exhibite them for a short time on different locations. After that nearly everyone can rent the crowns from me. And I want to show the crowns on special events.

5. I don't live into the Netherlands can i rent the crowns?

A: Yes, It's possible. But for that information you need to wait till the crowns are made.

 

 

If you have other questions for me or you want some other information please contact me. Thank you very much for visiting this site. It would be great if you support me with my dream project. Thank you and cheers!

Contact: the4crownproject@gmail.com

story:
By far the best way to learn a new language is by speaking with natives.

I've spent the last six years or so trying to find the best way of learning a secondary language. While there are many great ways of building vocabulary, memorizing conjugations and all-around filling your mind with useful information, absolutely nothing beats the experience and acquisition of knowledge that can be accomplished by talking to a native speaker.

Whether you're starting out in your secondary language, almost fluent, but need more practice or you just need someone to talk to so you don't lose it, Lingua Parla is your solution.

After registering, a person must simply fill out the information about what language they can speak and the language they want to learn or otherwise practice, and they will be matched to someone with whom they can practice.

In addition to matching with specific people, a user will be able to search the chat rooms for someone to practice with and strike up a conversation at their own consent.

Your payment to the other person is time: The person to whom you are talking is also there to learn a second language (we matched them to you because you speak the language they want to learn). Each conversation will last 15 minutes, 30 minutes, an hour or whatever the two people agree on. Half will be spent speaking in one language and the second half in another (a soft alarm will go off when it's time to switch).

Lingua will offer multiple facets. The main one will be video chat because it's easier to understand people and learn given facial expressions and hand gestures. However, Lingua Parla will also offer voice and text chat for those without a webcam or suitable internet connection.

The best way to learn a language is to go to a country that speaks it and immerse yourself in the language. That option is not available to most people, and the aim of every language learning software is to find the next best thing.

Lingua Parla, of course, is Italian for "The Tongue Speaks". Lingua itself is also understood as tongue by most people around the world.

$2500 (in addition to the time and money I'm investing) is the bare minimum to get this started (cost of servers). However, the long-run cost is in the tens of thousands of dollars. Any donations after reaching the initial $2500 are greatly appreciated.

Even if you can't contribute financially, please consider sharing the project on any social media platform and telling people how cool it is. The more people we can behind this the better!

In addition, if you are willing to volunteer time, I'm looking for designers, developers and pretty much anyone who wants to help. Contact me at c.ostmo@gmail.com with any ideas.

Thank you so much for helping make this a reality!
story_txt:
By far the best way to learn a new language is by speaking with natives. 
I've spent the last six years or so trying to find the best way of learning a secondary language. While there are many great ways of building vocabulary, memorizing conjugations and all-around filling your mind with useful information, absolutely nothing beats the experience and acquisition of knowledge that can be accomplished by talking to a native speaker.
Whether you're starting out in your secondary language, almost fluent, but need more practice or you just need someone to talk to so you don't lose it, Lingua Parla is your solution.
After registering, a person must simply fill out the information about what language they can speak and the language they want to learn or otherwise practice, and they will be matched to someone with whom they can practice.
In addition to matching with specific people, a user will be able to search the chat rooms for someone to practice with and strike up a conversation at their own consent.
Your payment to the other person is time: The person to whom you are talking is also there to learn a second language (we matched them to you because you speak the language they want to learn). Each conversation will last 15 minutes, 30 minutes, an hour or whatever the two people agree on. Half will be spent speaking in one language and the second half in another (a soft alarm will go off when it's time to switch).

Lingua will offer multiple facets. The main one will be video chat because it's easier to understand people and learn given facial expressions and hand gestures. However, Lingua Parla will also offer voice and text chat for those without a webcam or suitable internet connection.
The best way to learn a language is to go to a country that speaks it and immerse yourself in the language. That option is not available to most people, and the aim of every language learning software is to find the next best thing.
Lingua Parla, of course, is Italian for "The Tongue Speaks". Lingua itself is also understood as tongue by most people around the world.
$2500 (in addition to the time and money I'm investing) is the bare minimum to get this started (cost of servers). However, the long-run cost is in the tens of thousands of dollars. Any donations after reaching the initial $2500 are greatly appreciated.
Even if you can't contribute financially, please consider sharing the project on any social media platform and telling people how cool it is. The more people we can behind this the better! 
In addition, if you are willing to volunteer time, I'm looking for designers, developers and pretty much anyone who wants to help. Contact me at c.ostmo@gmail.com with any ideas.
Thank you so much for helping make this a reality!

story:
We are a group of 18 graduating seniors who are Bachelor of Arts and Bachelor of Fine Arts majors at Ohio Wesleyan University.  We created this website to campaign for our Senior Art Show that we are putting together at The Ross Museum in Delaware, Ohio.  This show will be a culmination of our works and will show a variety of mediums that represent our abilities as artists.

Your support will help us fund our final show which involves a variety of costs, including advertising, reception, installation, and exhibition booklets.  We are excited to host this event and hope that you can become a part of the exciting process through your donations.  Donations that are $100 or more will guarantee your name to be published in our exhibition booklets that will be given to all attending reception guests.

We thank you for your support and appreciate any amount!  We hope to see you at our opening reception on April 12th from 5:00PM- 7:00PM at The Ross Museum.  All are welcome, help us spread the word!

story:
Short Summary

Hey there! I'm Jim Myers: Biker/Artist.  I've been into making art since the age of 2.  Really! I started drawing at around age 2.   I started painting at about age 14.  That's also the age I became passionate about motorcycles!  I decided to dedicate myself to the creation of art, seriously, about 10 years ago.  I'll admit it! I want to make a decent living at it.  

My idea, here, is to raise the funds to supply my studio with enough canvases and good quality acryllic paints to continue producing my paintings of motorcycle life, hot rods, classic cars, and basically any kind of paintings that the people who seek my services are looking for.  Also, I'm trying to gather up the funds to buy a small enclosed trailer, and a pro-panels set up so I can have a "mobile gallery" to take to bike shows, art shows, and hopefully, the Sturgis Bike Rally!

The folks who contribute to my campaign will be helping an artist who loves art more than anything achieve his dream of being a "professional artist".  And, for that, I would be eternally grateful!

What We Need & What You Get

I'm looking to raise $10,000!  A major chunk of that will go toward the equipment I need to have myself a "mobile gallery" set-up to take my art to the people who would enjoy it the most.  Here's an approximate breakdown of where the money would go:

  • Pro Panel display set-up and LED lighting kit:  Approx. $2100
  • 6'x10' (or 12') enclosed trailer:  Approx. $3000
  • Canvases, paint, and other studio supplies:  Approx. $2000 - $3000
  • Throw a little in the bank so I can afford to go to shows:  Whatever's left.
People who contribute wouldn't be "throwing their cash to the wind", so to speak.  I'll offer some pretty cool perks!  I make a Biker Art calendar that's pretty popular, at least among people I know.  I'll also offer prints, both unframed AND framed!  For those who want to contribute a lot of money, I'll even offer to do some original paintings of whatever they would like!

The Impact

My goal in life, as an artist, is to make people happy when they look at their walls!  I love doing paintings for people who want to memorialize someone, or remember something cool that they were part of, or a favorite vehicle ( motorcycle or car).  I also love doing art that represents the "Biker" lifestyle that I, and many other people, live and breathe everyday.  All my life, I've striven to make people happy.  I happen to believe that art does that very thing.  I'm also looking to start giving painting lessons to people, locally!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

If you can't contribute money, please by all means, share this campaign with everyone you know, or have ever met in life!!

I would sure be grateful and most appreciative!

story:
A Little About Me...

With a BFA in Interior Architecture and experience as a Costume Designer in Los Angeles, I have decided to continue my education and pursue my true interests in Textile Design! At FIDM I will learn industry standards so that I can work in the field providing sustainable design with a hand made sensibility to local communities. As a Textile Designer I will be able to engage in collaborations with a variety of designers in designing beautiful and sustainable objects that represent a community's identity through their art of living. 

What I need...

Tuition for this one year program at FIDM is $35,000. (This is after my awarded FIDM scholarship is applied.) FIDM offers one year programs for designers with prior degrees so that they may build upon their design skills and learn industry standards to prepare them for immediate job placement. 

I need to finalize my payment plan by August 1, 2016 so that I can register for classes that start in October, 2016.

If you are so kind as to contribute to my continued education I will send my sincere thanks and a hand made gift for your enjoyment! All gifts are one of a kind although I've included images below of what your gift may look like!

With a $10 contribution, you will receive a one of a kind hand marbled thank you card! With a $20 contribution, you will receive an original hand dyed tote bag! With a contribution of $50, you will receive an original hand dyed pillow! At $100, contributors will receive a one of a kind hand dyed sweatshirt! A $200 donation will provide you with a matching hand dyed sweatshirt and pants set! At $500, you will receive a sweatshirt and pants set AND an original hand dyed tote! At $1000, you will receive a sweatshirt and pants set, a tote, AND a pillow. 

The Impact

With your support, I will finish the program at FIDM in the fall of 2017 with a diverse Textile Design portfolio that will earn me a job as a Textile Designer. As a professional, I will strive to promote sustainable and accessible design and work to empower local communities through instilling art into their daily lives.

Risks and Challenges

My commitment to providing sustainable and empowering design might limit my employment options when searching for companies to work for. Despite this, I am willing to accept the challenge so that I may honestly express myself as a designer. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a contribution, spreading the word of my campaign through indiegogo's share tools will be greatly appreciated! Thanks for your support!

$10 contribution: Hand marbled card 

$20 contribution and $500 and up: Hand dyed tote bag $50 and $1000 contribution: Hand dyed pillow

$100 contribution: Hand dyed sweatshirt

$200 and $1000 contribution: Hand dyed sweatsuit

story:
Introducing the A to Z of Caribbean Art

For the past year, the team at Robert & Christopher Publishers has been hard at work on our forthcoming art book: the A to Z of Caribbean Art. We're passionate about this project and its potential reach and longevity, and we're looking forward to your support in helping us to bring it to life.

The A to Z of Caribbean Art will offer a comprehensive, visual overview of the development of Caribbean art, from the beginning of the 20th century, to now. The A to Z will be a key resource of information on the greatest artists of the region. With artists listed alphabetically, instead of being grouped by traditional methods, this book will move seamlessly through artists and genres including drawing, painting, sculpture, photography, installation, and performance.

The A to Z will feature a short introduction by R&C's editors, Melanie Archer and Mariel Brown, followed by the works. Each artist will be represented by a spread that will show a definitive work and will also provide biographical details on each artist: year of birth, year of death (if applicable), country of birth and residence, a 300-word statement about their oeuvre, and the name of the work that represents them, along with dimensions, medium and genres.

The artists who will be featured in the A to Z come from the English-, Dutch-, French- and Spanish-speaking Caribbean. We've chosen this illustrious group based on a number of factors, including critical discourse around their work, inclusion in a significant publication, work written about in regional or international trade magazine, and participation in a curated exhibition at a major institution, or at a regional or international biennial. 

Here are a few key A to Z specs:
7.5 x 10 in. (portrait)
Printing full colour throughout
416 pages, 350gsm matte paper
Smyth-sewn binding
Flexibound
 

 

Where We're At

We have completed about 50% of the research involved in making a seminal book such as the A to Z of Caribbean Art. We’ve built extensive artists’ lists, reached out across the islands to advisors, compiled our list of contributing writers, and hired a researcher. We have a designer on board, we're actively seeking sponsorship; we’ve got print quotes and a marketing plan. We are so close to our April 2018 publication date, but we need to raise our printing costs to publish this book.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

One of our missions at Robert & Christopher is to produce books at an accessible price point. In order to do this, we need to fundraise to partly cover our production and printing costs. With your contribution, we will be able to keep the price of A to Z within a range that will be affordable to a wide market that includes students. This price, along with the accessibility of the subject matter, solid editing and writing, and beautiful design, will make this a book everyone will want to have in their libraries. With your support, we will also be able to ensure posterity, and that this title will be highly visible through the Caribbean and internationally, thereby helping to raise the profile of regional art and artists.

We’re using the Indiegogo platform for both fundraising and as an opportunity to offer advance orders of the A to Z of Caribbean Art.  Your contributions can come in several forms:

1. Advance order(s) of A to Z
2. Advance order(s) with added perks
3. Perks
4. Donations

We've developed some fantastic perks for your contributions; we're particularly thrilled to have teamed up with some of the Caribbean's most exciting artists – who will be included in the book – to offer highly collectible works of art. Other perks include advance orders of A to Z, and items that art and book lovers would enjoy like postcard packs, tote bags, R&C's former titles, sketchbooks, and more!  Scroll down to the bottom of the campaign homepage to see our perks.

 

 

The Impact

While the A to Z of Caribbean Art is Caribbean-focused, it was born out of a spirit of mass appeal. In conceiving this book, we realised that it would be desirable to a broad range of people across many divides. Its Caribbean focus naturally creates an audience within this region, but also makes it a valuable collector’s item within the large and growing circle of international art players who have been increasingly keen to absorb the Caribbean’s artistic output.

The A to Z of Caribbean Art will appeal to:
Artists
Art lovers 
Art collectors
Art administrators
Caribbean art institutions (museums and galleries)
International art institutions (museums and galleries)
Caribbean students (secondary, tertiary, and doctorate levels)
Caribbean libraries
Art scholars
Professors and students of Caribbean studies
Curators
Designers
Book lovers and collectors
Art historians
Writers and editors
Culture lovers

At Robert & Christopher, we believe in the power of documentation and connection. Our books (and the launches and talks around them) have led to meaningful and lasting artist connections and collaborations. They've been vessels for discourse and dialogue on Caribbean art, and have created further publication and exhibition opportunities for our artists. Among these, in 2014 we were invited to co-curate an exhibition, “Pictures from Paradise,” with Wedge Curatorial Projects in Toronto, Canada, as part of the annual CONTACT Photography Festival – the largest public photography festival in the world. We're also the first Caribbean imprint to have a title distributed by Distributed Art Publishers. These advancements came out of pure dedication and a tremendous love for art, as well as our desire to do our part to help ensure posterity. With your help, we will keep pushing for quality visibility for Caribbean art and artists.


 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially, please put in a good word for us and post, Tweet and share this page (using the Indiegogo share tools whenever possible). Every bit helps.

If you have any questions, please send them our way, we'd be glad to hear from you! Email us at melanie@robertandchristopher.com or mariel@robertandchristopher.com.

 

 

About Robert & Christopher

Robert & Christopher Publishers (R&C) is a small and ambitious illustrated art book imprint based in Trinidad and Tobago. Our primary concern is to produce high-quality books that document and elucidate our Caribbean story, as seen through the eyes of Caribbean artists. We aim to produce insightful, relevant books that will be accessible to a wide reading and creative audience throughout the Caribbean and internationally.

Robert & Christopher’s mission is to help open up critical dialogue for and amongst Caribbean people, and to explore and record the work of regional artists from a local perspective. By keeping a low price point on all our titles, we aim to create go-to texts that are accessible to artists, students of art, art lovers, and critics within the region. And, by maintaining high intellectual and production standards, R&C aims to appeal to international art and publishing markets.

In addition to our most recent title, See Me Here: A Survey of Contemporary Self-Portraits from the Caribbean, Robert & Christopher has also published: Pictures from Paradise: A Survey of Contemporary Caribbean Photography, Che Lovelace: Paintings 2004 – 2008, Meiling: Fashion Designer and Barbara Jardine: Goldsmith. In 2014, we were invited to co-curate an exhibition, “Pictures from Paradise,” with Wedge Curatorial Projects in Toronto, Canada, as part of the annual CONTACT Photography Festival – the largest public photography festival in the world.

 

About the team

Check Out Our Perks!

story:
Our Story

In 2010 artists Hernan Barros and Omar Castañeda founded the 'Food Of War' Collective.

The ‘Food of War’  Collective is dedicated to exploring the relationship between Food and Conflict through art. It is a Non-Profit initiative whose aims include creating art and events raising awareness about the impact of armed conflicts around the world. ‘Food of War’ develops art, cultural and community projects using food to bond with the audience and relay our message.

Since 2010 ‘Food of War’ have been travelling around the world, exploring conflicts and political circumstances where food plays a key role. The collective have exhibited in Spain, Germany, Ukraine, Mexico, Peru, Brazil and The United Kingdom, working with subjects as diverse as the Venezuelan Crisis and the 30th anniversary of the Chernobyl disaster and as guests in several international art fairs.

Throughout these projects, ‘Food of War’ has collaborated with local artists on exhibitions, growing with their perspective and knowledge. Working with the community is an integral part of the collective's art practice, involving not only artists but also social causes related to the themes.

 

'Food Of War' in post-conflict Colombia

The founders of 'Food of War' are both Colombian immigrants living in London. Returning to their native Colombia this project marks the peak of an intense cycle. Barros and Castañeda feel an urgency to work with their home country especially in this turbulent political moment where the peace treaty of 2016 is under threat.

’Food of War’ in Colombia marks the beginning of a new journey where the Collective and guest artists will be fuelled by the complexity of their home country and its history of food related conflict as well as its initiatives to bring healing and empowerment through working with food.

 

The relationship between Food & Conflict in Colombia

Colombia is one of the most resource rich and biodiverse countries on the planet. With an economy based on exportation of natural resources including oil, flowers and gold, Colombia has for centuries endured conflict connected to land distribution and exploitation of raw materials and those who have cultivated them.

Ranked in the top four for inequality, Colombia’s conflict has been tied to the misallocation of natural resources including crops, water and land. Food has been a key issue, connected to the structural lack of support for local farmers, the presence of paramilitary and guerrilla factions controlling large areas of land and furthermore the eradication programmes using biological warfare to eradicate plantations with the long-term affect of ruining soil and food crops.

With the signing of a Peace Treaty in 2016, food has become the path to leave behind the war and embrace a new era in harmony not only with the environment but with each other. Initiatives to embrace new crops, innovative ways of trading and engaging with a global economy are a few of the strategies related to food as the route to leave the illegality and build a new Colombia. What once was the root of conflict, is now the reason to embrace peace.

 

We need your help

Due to Colombia’s recent history of conflict, its national institutions do not have funding to financially support such a project. Therefore the invited artists have been asked to raise support internationally to realise this exhibition.

This exhibition could have an enormous impact on its audience. Highlighting narratives of post-conflict Colombia whilst helping people to understand the political nuanced history of the country this exhibition seeks to empower and educate in an accessible and inspiring way.

The attention on Colombia is too often associated with its narco-history. This exhibition will show an international audience another narrative and forge new collaborations with Colombian artists and communities across Colombia.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising £30,000 in order to:

What we need your contribution for:


1. Developing workshops for the community affected by the conflict in Colombia. This will
include indigenous communities from the Amazon, displaced people by the conflict, the
trans community in Bogota and migrants from Venezuela.
2. To help with the cost of artwork produced by the community together with the artists.
3. To organised talks that will create a space for dialogue between the community and artists.
4. To organise a gastroperformace inviting the community on the opening day.
5. To invite other local collectives and ngos to display their work with vulnerable groups.

 

For those who cannot experience the exhibition in Colombia, the Food of War Collective are organising a beauty pageant in London based on the themes of the exhibition with costumes exploring Food which has arisen from conflict. Tickets are included in the perks section. The event reflects the Colombian obsession with pageants and offers a vibrant evening of entertainment and learning about the subject of the exhibition. The winner of pageant will be invited to exhibit their costume in the next Food of War exhibition. 

 

Our Track Record

We have curated 10 critically acclaimed international exhibitions in public and private institutions. The impact of these projects has been enormous with over 6000 visitors at our Chernobyl Commemoration Exhibition in Kiev and over 20,000 collectively over all of our shows. We have worked with over 60 international artists and run over 100 workshops engaging with groups varying from refugees, conflict victims and survivors, immigrants, internally displaced people, children, elderly communities and general art audiences.

The power of our projects is far reaching. With each project we have created we have been approached by new institutions asking us to bring new developments of 'Food of War' to their countries.

For us as Colombians this new project is particularly important, however because Colombia is outside of the EU it is particularly different to get public funding for. This is why we really need your support. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Curating an exhibition in a post-conflict country certainly has its challenges. However, our collectives strong ties with Colombia and the Museum of Contemporary Art in Bogotá means we have a very strong support network and are extremely confident we can deliver this project to its full potential.

With this in mind and understanding the complexity of organising an international project coordinating 16 artists across 8 countries we are working with 2 curators who will help to manage from within and outside of Colombia. Gabriella Sonabend our international curator will look after the international artists and will manage the production budget ensuring artists are able to produce ambitious works and workshops. Juan David Quintero the in-house curator at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Bogotá will manage and coordinate the Colombian artists and help to facilitate the local projects and collaborations.

Lead artist Omar Castañeda is making regular trips to Colombia in the run up to the show to help to organise materials and other necessary elements for the visiting artists. He is liaising directly with the museum to ensure everything is on schedule. Although the museum cannot provide financial support they are looking to support in other ways by facilitating performances and workshops, helping to reach the right demographics and with PR support.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount you can contribute towards this projects is enormously appreciated. If you are unable to contribute financially please share this project with a friend and let us know if there are any other ways you would like to get involved.

Our Story
In 2010 artists Hernan Barros and Omar Castañeda founded the 'Food Of War' Collective.
The ‘Food of War’  Collective is dedicated to exploring the relationship between Food and Conflict through art. It is a Non-Profit initiative whose aims include creating art and events raising awareness about the impact of armed conflicts around the world. ‘Food of War’ develops art, cultural and community projects using food to bond with the audience and relay our message.
Since 2010 ‘Food of War’ have been travelling around the world, exploring conflicts and political circumstances where food plays a key role. The collective have exhibited in Spain, Germany, Ukraine, Mexico, Peru, Brazil and The United Kingdom, working with subjects as diverse as the Venezuelan Crisis and the 30th anniversary of the Chernobyl disaster and as guests in several international art fairs.
Throughout these projects, ‘Food of War’ has collaborated with local artists on exhibitions, growing with their perspective and knowledge. Working with the community is an integral part of the collective's art practice, involving not only artists but also social causes related to the themes.
 
'Food Of War' in post-conflict Colombia
The founders of 'Food of War' are both Colombian immigrants living in London. Returning to their native Colombia this project marks the peak of an intense cycle. Barros and Castañeda feel an urgency to work with their home country especially in this turbulent political moment where the peace treaty of 2016 is under threat.
’Food of War’ in Colombia marks the beginning of a new journey where the Collective and guest artists will be fuelled by the complexity of their home country and its history of food related conflict as well as its initiatives to bring healing and empowerment through working with food.
 
The relationship between Food & Conflict in Colombia

To help with the cost of artwork produced by the community together with the artists.3. To organised talks that will create a space for dialogue between the community and artists.4. To organise a gastroperformace inviting the community on the opening day.5. To invite other local collectives and ngos to display their work with vulnerable groups. For those who cannot experience the exhibition in Colombia, the Food of War Collective are organising a beauty pageant in London based on the themes of the exhibition with costumes exploring Food which has arisen from conflict. Tickets are included in the perks section. The event reflects the Colombian obsession with pageants and offers a vibrant evening of entertainment and learning about the subject of the exhibition. story:
Every Square is a Rectangle

Mackenzie Browning created the screen-print series Every Square is a Rectangle with the goal of selling the prints to support Urban Peak. The series is made up of three unique prints, Every Square is a Rectangle I, Every Square is a Rectangle II, and Every Square is a Rectangle III. Each print is part of a limited edition of 20.

Each print is hand screen-printed on acid-free, cotton rag paper using environmentally-friendly processes. Each print is 9x12" and will be delivered unframed between two pieces of protective board. You can choose to have the work custom framed, or it will fit beautifully in a standard 11x14" frame.

70% of all funds collected will be donated directly to Urban Peak, with the remainder covering shipping and material expenses.

About The Artist

Mackenzie Browning is a Denver based artist who works primarily in screen-print, book arts, and print based sculpture. Mackenzie’s aesthetic can be described as bold, meticulous, and inventive, often blurring the lines between design, craft and fine art. His artworks are constantly pushing personal technical boundaries, often becoming architectural in nature. Mackenzie’s creations and installations reflect both his past and present lived experiences, a personal history that has primarily taken place in the suburban construct. More information can be found at www.mackenziebrowning.com

About Urban Peak

Founded in 1988, Urban Peak is the only non-profit organization in Denver that provides a full convergence of services for youth ages 15 through 24 experiencing homelessness or at imminent risk of becoming homeless. Their goal is to help these youth overcome real life challenges and become self-sufficient adults.

They do this by providing five essential services to the youth:

  • an overnight shelter
  • a daytime Drop-In Center
  • Street Outreach
  • Education & Employment programming
  • Supportive housing

Urban Peak's goal is to meet youth where they are and to provide them with the assistance and support they need to become self-sufficient or obtain the necessary services they need to exit a life on the streets. Urban Peak’s programs and services are founded on the principles of trauma-informed care and positive youth development and assist youth in reaching their potential and living a successful life off of the streets.

www.urbanpeak.org

Other Ways You Can Help

Please consider volunteering or donating directly to Urban Peak, even if you decide not to take part in this campaign!

story:
Arthwind's very first Art Zine!!

Hello Everyone, my name is Lucid AJ and I'm the creator and artist for Arthwind! Arthwind is an online webcomic available to read online for free on Webtoons and Tapas!

The reason for this campaign is to be able to print our very first Arthwind Art Zine!! The Art Zine will contain a variety of Arthwind artwork including finished illustrations to fun sketches. The funds collected will help print the zine and to help us continue the webcomic!

  • 24 pages (cover+20 pages)
  • Saddle Stitch Binding
  • Size: 6x9 inches
  • Bonus: Includes 2 pieces of 1.5" circular-shaped Stickers!

 

Want more than just the Art Zine? We have Charms, Sketches and Digital Commissions available!

 

Timeline
April - Production
May - Printing
June - Ready to Ship!!

 


 

The project has reached its goal and all the stretch goals so therefore 
all physical perks will receive their items and the additional stretch goal rewards of
2 (4x6") prints and 1.5" button!!
 

 

 

o((*^▽^*))o     THANK YOU!!     o((*^▽^*))o

story:
Short Summary

Sign up to receive updates on the eBook

About Feryal Abbasi-Ghnaim

About Wafa Ghnaim

My mother, Feryal Abbasi-Ghnaim, is the leading Palestinian folk artist specializing in fabric and fiber arts in the United States. She is of the Nakba generation, who left Palestine in 1948 -- and has dedicated her over 50 year career in teaching young women of color the endangered art of Palestinian embroidery and traditional art that she learned from her mother and grandmother. She has worked nearly without pay, only on grant funds, for decades -- in order to teach her apprentices the skill of embroidering by hand. She has been funded and honored by countless organizations, including the Oregon Historical Society, Oral History Center of Cambridge, Oregon Folklife Network, National Endowment of the Arts and the Regional Arts & Culture Council. A brief idea of her involvement in the Palestinian diaspora community can be found on her website: https://feryalabbasighnaim.wordpress.com/. 

As new generations of Palestinians are raised in diaspora, it is becoming more crucial than ever to document our endangered traditional art of embroidery, the designs, meanings, context and history. I would like to assist my mother in translating, transcribing and publishing a series of e-books that give voice to our matriarchal ancestors, document oral history, as well as preserve the sacred tradition of Palestinian storytelling. We have attempted to fund this project entirely on our own over the last 8 years, and after my mother's injury last year -- I realized that I cannot hold back any longer. I need to write this book while I can, and I need your help. I cannot do this alone.

My mother and I need a laptop and audio recording device. If possible, my mother needs desperately to upgrade her phone so we can communicate more effectively (I live in New York and she lives in Portland, Oregon). With all the expenses we have and will incur as it relates to this book project, we are trying to alleviate the financial burden by crowdsourcing equipment.

What We Need & What You Get

We are currently applying to grants, to help fund the first of the series (15 designs) to be published in an electronic format by the end of 2016. None of the grants available to us will fund equipment for this book project. I need to purchase a new laptop and audio recording device in order to record interviews with my mother, and travel back and forth from New York (where I live) to Oregon (where my mother lives). I need to interview her in Arabic, record, translate and transcribe the content, as well as photograph the designs in a studio (which hopefully will be funded by the grants we've applied for). Please review the perks of this campaign to know how we will honor your contribution. Everyone who donates $5 or more will be considered a founding investor of the book and will be honored.

Goal Budget:
New laptop: $1099
Audio Recorder: Olympus Voice Recorder with Built-In-Memory: $47
2 Micro SD Cards: $23 each ($46 total)

= $1192

Stretch Budget:
Large monitor for my mother, $250
VHS to DVD Converter $80
Photograph and newspaper portable scanner (archival) $60

= $390

Grand Total = $1582 +5% = $1661

(Indiegogo takes 5% off the top, and payment processors have an additional fee)

Anything raised in addition will be saved to fill any grant funding deficits. We are told of the grant panel decisions December, 2015.

I have 4 trips budgeted to Oregon, to research the book, in our grants -- between now and December 31, 2016. The proposed goal to our grant funders is that the ebook will be published by December 31, 2016.

The Impact

Oral storytelling is an intimate experience, and in Palestinian women's culture it is done through a familial mentorship over a lifetime. My mother learned these stories through her mother and grandmother. As generations of Palestinian women grow in diaspora, our identities and stories remain silently coded in our needle and thread. But our ancestors stories cannot be forgotten. In publishing the meanings of our traditional designs, we give voice to our matriarchal ancestors, document oral history, as well as preserve the sacred tradition of Palestinian storytelling in women's craft circles. 

Also, this book will be a unique, unprecedented literary contribution to the field of Palestinian folk art. The few and only books published about Palestinian embroidery share the beauty of the designs -- however, not a single book provides historical context or meaning behind what the designs on the garments mean. This book will decode our art for future generations to come -- and is in a downloadable format online. No other Palestinian embroidery book is offered in this format online.

Palestinian women's stories are documented through the designs -- a coded language used by women over centuries to communicate to one another -- which is decoded through dialogues between mother and daughter. In the same tradition, my mother and I would like to lock arms with you to make this long awaited dream come true -- not just for ourselves, but for all Palestinian women and men in diaspora who are seeking to construct their cultural identities outside of the political arena.

Risks & Challenges

There is a chance that our grants will not be funded through various funders and we will not have money to publish this ebook in 2016. In this case, we will need to increase the Indiegogo campaign to accommodate our full project budget. Please be assured that before I do this, I will apply to as many grants as we qualify for to get this project off the ground. I've fundraised for high profile Palestinian nonprofits in Washington, DC and New York -- and I feel confident that with enough will, I can get our project funded. Worse-case scenario is that the book is not electronically published by December 31, 2016 and it ends up being published in 2017. We will keep you updated on our process, so this will not come to a surprise. We honor and cherish your contributions and will do everything in our power to mitigate these risks.
